revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Amir Gal-Or |image = Image001AmirGalOr.jpg |image_size = 150px |caption = Amir Gal-Or, 2006 |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1962|09|05}} |birth_place = [[Israel]] |occupation = [[Entrepreneur]], [[Venture Capitalist]] based in [[China]] }} '''Amir Gal-Or''' (Hebrew: אמיר גלאור) (born 1962) is an [[Israel]]i businessman. He is the Founder and Managing Partner of [[Infinity Group]]<ref name="Bacani">{{cite web|url=http://prasad.aem.cornell.edu/doc/media/CFOAsia.June2008.pdf |title=Bacani, Cesar. "To infinity and Beyond China is developing a local private-equity industry partly at the expense of foreign investment firms. But one Israeli fund has discovered an unlikely path to success", CFO Asia, June 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100626074746/http://prasad.aem.cornell.edu/doc/media/CFOAsia.June2008.pdf |archivedate=June 26, 2010 }}</ref><ref name="Gelsi S">{{cite news | url = http://www.marketwatch.com/story/china-ipos-flow-as-venture-fund-eyes-future-listings | title= China IPOs continue in U.S. Israeli venture fund raises $155 mln for China firms |publisher=Marketwatch |date=May 15, 2007 |author=Steve Gelsi}}</ref><ref name="Xinhua 1">{{cite news | url = http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90776/90883/6640160.html | title= Int'l credit crunch shifts Israeli business focus in China |date=April 20, 2009 |agency=Xinhua}}</ref><ref name="CLPA">{{cite news |url = http://www.clpa.cc/English/ShowArticle.asp?ArticleID=508 | title= Israel PE Fund Infinity: Investment Price is not everything in China |publisher=CLPA |date=2009-05-10}}{{dead link|date=August 2014}}</ref>, and Founder and Chairman of Innonation. Gal-Or served as a pilot in the [[Israeli Air Force]].<ref name=interview>{{cite news|url=http://www.globes.co.il/news/docview.aspx?did=1000131015 |last=Feldman |first=Batya |script-title=he:הרמת המסך של אמיר גלאור |language=he |trans-title=Raising the Curtain on Amir Gal-Or |newspaper=[[Globes]] |date=September 7–8, 2006 |page=6 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927081610/http://www.globes.co.il/news/docview.aspx?did=1000131015 |archivedate=2011-09-27 |df= }}</ref>
==Biography== Gal-Or was born on September 5, 1962, in [[Haifa]], Israel. His parents, Leah and Benjamin, are professors at the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology. Gal-Or's mother specializes in [[chemistry]] and [[materials science|materials]]; his father specializes in [[machinery]].<ref name="interview"/> Gal-Or attended the [[Hebrew Reali School]] in Haifa, where he graduated from the Science-Physics Department.<ref name=interview/> Gal-Or earned a [[BSc]] in [[economics]] and [[business management]] from the [[University of Haifa]] and an [[MBA]] from [[Tel Aviv University]]. Later he graduated from [[Harvard University]]'s program in venture capital and [[private equity]] investments.<ref name=interview/>
Gal-Or has four children: Raz, Amit, Talia and Hila.<ref name=interview/>
==Air force career== Gal-Or served as a combat pilot in the [[Israeli Air Force]] (IDF/AF) for 24 years, flying the [[F-4 Phantom]], [[F-16]] and [[A-4 Skyhawk]].<ref name=interview/> He was also a member of the IDF/AF aerobatic team. On October 16, 1986, he flew in the same formation with Israeli MIA navigator/weapon systems officer (WSO) [[Ron Arad (pilot)|Ron Arad]], who went missing that day. Gal-Or is retired from active reserve duty and serves as an instructor in the military flying school.<ref name=interview/>
==Business career== [[File:AmirGalOr VentureAssociationCon.jpg|250px|thumb|Amir Gal-Or addresses attendees of the Israel Venture Association Conference in [[Tel Aviv]]]]
Gal-Or's career as a private entrepreneur began at the Technion incubator in 1990 upon completing seven years of army service.<ref name=themarker>{{cite news|url=http://it.themarker.com/tmit/article/1946 |last=Grimland |first=Guy |title=Amir Gal-Or: This will be a brain power community |work=The Marker |date=November 21, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071123191353/http://it.themarker.com/tmit/article/1946 |archivedate=November 23, 2007 }}</ref> He returned home to Haifa, registered at the [[University of Haifa]] and, together with his mother,<ref name=Hermoni>{{cite web | url=http://www.haaretz.co.il/news/health/1.1070474 |last=Hermoni |first=Oded |script-title=he:באו בגלל הכסף, נשארו בשביל הכיף |language=he |trans-title=Came for the money, stayed for fun |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |date=December 26, 2005 |accessdate=August 18, 2014}}</ref> established two materials companies: TAN, developing high-grade refractory [[ceramic]] [[oxides]], and a venture with the largest Israeli fuels company: [[Paz Oil Company Ltd.|Paz]] Oil Company. Eventually, the latter venture integrated with Paz in exchange for royalties, and TAN was sold.<ref name=interview/> In 1994, Gal-Or was nominated as a manager of Mati Ra'anana, a business development center in [[Ra'anana]] jointly established by the [[American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee|JDC]], the Ministry of Absorption, the Israel Small and Medium Enterprise Authority ([[ISMEA]]), [http://www.esra.org.il/ ESRA] organization, and the Ra'anana Municipality. Mati Ra'anana provides professional consulting services, business plan formulation, professional business training, on-going consulting and mentoring, and assistance in obtaining the necessary funding to realize the goals set in the business plan assistance to small and medium sized businesses, and technological start ups. Gal-Or founded a special forum for startup ventures in Mati Ra'anana.
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Infinity Group Shanghai China IPO pic.jpeg|thumb|right|alt=Infinity Group founder and managing partner and WLCSP board member Amir Gal-Or (directly on the right of bell) together with Israeli Consul General to Shanghai Arnon Perlman (next to Gal-Or) ring the opening bell at the Shanghai stock exchange in honor of WLCSP's IPO, February 10, 2014.|Infinity Group founder and managing partner and WLCSP board member Amir Gal-Or (directly on the right of bell) together with Israeli Consul General to Shanghai Arnon Perlman (next to Gal-Or) ring the opening bell at the Shanghai stock exchange in honor of WLCSP's IPO, February 10, 2014.]] --> In 1998, Gal-Or switched to venture capital<ref name=interview/> and helped found [[Infinity Group]].<ref name=Hermoni/> In 2002 the [[Office of the Chief Scientist (Israel)|Office of the Chief Scientist]] (OCS) of Israel began a program to privatize the [[technology incubator]]s. Under the umbrella of Infinity, Gal-Or founded Maayan Ventures, a publicly traded company, where he serves as chairman. Maayan, headquartered in [[Beersheva]], is a working partner of the Israeli government for seed investments and manages more than 60 investment holdings. Infinity also operates technology incubators in [[Dimona]] and [[Sde Boker]] and is purchasing a share in the incubator in [[Ofakim]]. Each incubator has a specialization and Infinity provides them with services and support.<ref name=themarker/>
Infinity, backed by the [[China Development Bank]] and Clal Industries, manages over 1.5 billion USD and has 23 funds, incubators, and accelerators established throughout China. Notable exits of the fund include: Galileo, Saifun, Shopping.com, ShellCase, Scitex Vision, Digital China, WLCSP, Bazun, and ITS.
In 2017, Gal-Or was bestowed with the [[Friendship Award (China)|Friendship Award]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cri.co.il/content/%D7%94%D7%99%D7%A9%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%9C%D7%99-%D7%90%D7%9E%D7%99%D7%A8-%D7%92%D7%9C-%D7%90%D7%95%D7%A8-%D7%96%D7%9B%D7%94-%D7%91%D7%AA%D7%95%D7%90%D7%A8-%D7%94%D7%9B%D7%91%D7%95%D7%93-%D7%94%D7%92%D7%91%D7%95%D7%94-%D7%91%D7%99%D7%95%D7%AA%D7%A8-%D7%9C%D7%96%D7%A8%D7%99%D7%9D-%D7%91%D7%A1%D7%99%D7%9F|title=הישראלי אמיר גל-אור זכה בתואר הכבוד הגבוה ביותר לזרים בסין {{!}} הרדיו הבינלאומי של סין (CRI)|last=International|first=China Radio|website=www.cri.co.il|language=he|access-date=2018-10-23}}</ref> by the Chinese government for his great contribution to China-Israel business relations over the past nearly two decades. The award is the highest honor granted to foreign experts by the Chinese government for their contributions to the country’s economic progress.
==See also== *[[Economy of Israel]] *[[Venture capital in Israel]] *[[Science and technology in Israel]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.cnbc.com/id/15840232?video=789227064&play=1 CNBC Asia's Cash Flow, Gal-Or discusses trends in the stock market and the strategic plans of the Infinity I-China Fund] July 9, 2008{{dead link|date=August 2014}}<!--Page loads but video, which has all the content, is missing--> *[http://finance.qq.com/a/20080927/001700.htm Finance.QQ.com] Infinity Equity managing partner Mr. Amir Gal-Or speaks to QQ.com at the World Economic Forum in Tianjin, China, about the activities of the I-China Fund, the status of the stock market and trends for the future. September 27, 2008. *[https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20100309-701292.html?mod=WSJ_World_MIDDLEHeadlinesMideast Online.wsj.com], Infinity Targets $513 Million For China Funds With A Foreign Twist, March 9, 2010, by Jonathan Shieber{{dead link|date=August 2014}} *[http://video.sina.com.cn/finance/hy/20090608/043518011.shtml Video.sina.com.cn] *[http://finance.qq.com/a/20090910/006853.htm Finance.qq.com] interview from WEF - the full text *[http://finance.qq.com/a/20090911/005393.htm Finance.qq.com] interview from WEF - the video *[http://google.com/search?q=cache:Tf9HUKAg8TwJ:blog.udn.com/clsc/3431776+To+Infinity+and+Beyond,+economist&cd=7&hl=en&ct=clnk, To Infinity and beyond - article at economist.com]{{dead link|date=August 2014}} *{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/video/intellectual-property-bank-forays-into-china/3D7B5AEB-4620-497A-B4A7-E9E85E56FDEC.html?mod=WSJ_article_related |title=Intellectual Property 'Bank' Forays Into China |author=Peter Stein |publisher=The Wall Street Journal |date=September 21, 2010}}

'''Andis Hadjicostis''' ([[Greek language|Greek]]: Άντης Χατζηκωστής; September 1968 in [[Nicosia]] - January 11, 2010<ref>{{cite news |title=A businessman well liked by associates and friends |author= |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-216453129.html |newspaper=[[Cyprus Mail]] |date=2010-01-13 |accessdate=2011-11-18}}</ref>) was a [[Cyprus|Cypriot]] [[businessman]] and [[media mogul]]. Hadjicostis is credited with creating [[Sigma TV]], a popular [[commercial television]] station in [[Cyprus]], serving as the station's [[CEO]].<ref name=mirror>{{cite news|first= |last= |title=Cyprus TV boss Andis Hadjicostis murdered in Nicosia |url=http://www.financialmirror.com/News/Cyprus_and_World_News/18938 |work=[[Financial Mirror]] |publisher= |date=2010-01-12 |accessdate=2010-02-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605031903/http://www.financialmirror.com/News/Cyprus_and_World_News/18938 |archivedate=2011-06-05 }}</ref> He also served as the CEO of the private, family-owned [[Dias Media Group]], which controls Cypriot television stations, radio and newspapers.<ref name=mirror/> Hadjicostis modernized and reformed Dias during his tenure.<ref name=mirror/>
Andis Hadjicostis was shot and killed with a shotgun on January 11, 2010, while leaving his home in the [[Engomi]] neighborhood of [[Nicosia]].<ref name=mirror/> He was 41 years old at the time of his murder.<ref name=mirror/>
The ''[[Simerini]]'', a Dias owned newspaper, printed the front page editorial [[headline]], "Cowardly murder – they killed Andy Hadjicostis in cold blood."<ref name=mirror/> [[Sigma TV]] switched to classical music programming on news of Hadjicostis' murder.<ref name=mirror/>
Cypriot police allege that Hadjicostis was murdered by a former employee, [[Elena Skordelli]], a presenter on one of the victim's television stations. Skordelli had recently been fired. Skordelli, her brother and two other men allegedly conspired to kill Hadjicostis.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/europe/10263451.stm BBC News: Cyprus TV host Elena Skordelli tried for murder]</ref>
Elena Skordeli, her brother and the two other suspects were sentenced to life in prison in June, 2013, for the conspiracy and murder of Andi Hadjikostis.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/the-sacked-tv-host-and-a-story-of-revenge--life-in-jail-for-mafiastyle-murder-of-millionaire-media-mogul-20130614-2o8y6.html | title=The sacked TV host and a story of revenge: life in jail for mafia-style murder of millionaire media mogul | work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] | date=14 June 2013 | accessdate=22 June 2013 | author=Charalambous, Charlie}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{See also|Ance (disambiguation)}} '''Associazione Nazionale Costruttori Edili''' ('''ANCE''') is the '''Italian Association of private construction contractors''', active in public works, residential and industrial building. It represents 20 regional organisations, 101 provincial associations and 20,000 construction companies of any specialization and dimension.
ANCE and its local associations safeguard the construction industry ''vis a vis'' the Government and Parliament, through its lobbying activity. ANCE also engages in dialogue with political, social and cultural Institutions.
ANCE ensures relationships with Administrative Authorities in governing the territory, planning investments and designing interventions.
ANCE and its local Associations offers assistance and consultancy services in the following fields: *legislative *economic and industrial relations
ANCE is engaged in: *Tendering for public procurement and relationships with the employers; *Public and private Financing; *Technical innovation and quality certification; *The implementation of fiscal regulations; *Company qualification for Public works
At the International level ANCE adheres to: *FIEC – [[European Construction Industry Federation]] *EIC – [[European International Contractors]] *UNICE – [[Union of Industrial and Employers' Confederations of Europe]] through ''Confindustria - Confederazione Generale dell’Industria Italiana'' *UEPC – ''Union Europeenne des Promoteurs-Constructeurs''
==External links== *[http://www.ance.it/ Official site (Italian)]
[[Category:Business organisations based in Italy]]

__NOTOC__ [[File:Astor Opera House crop.jpg|thumb|right|350px|The Astor Opera House in 1850]] [[File:Clinton Hall Mercantile Library Bldg 13 Astor Place.jpg|thumb|right|187px|This 11-story building, now condominiums, replaced the opera house building in 1890]] The '''Astor Opera House''', also known as the '''Astor Place Opera House''' and later the '''Astor Place Theatre''',Not the same as the current [[Astor Place Theatre]] was an opera house in [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], located on [[Lafayette Street (Manhattan)|Lafayette Street]] between [[Astor Place]] and [[8th Street (Manhattan)|East 8th Street]]. Designed by [[Isaiah Rogers]], the theater was conceived by impresario Edward Fry, the brother of composer [[William Henry Fry]], who managed the opera house during its entire history.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8oks8-lgwlgC&pg=PA75&dq=%22Baltimore%22+%22Max+Maretzek%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAGoVChMIwofsuu3yxgIVA9SACh01QQeF#v=onepage&q=%22Baltimore%22%20%22Max%20Maretzek%22&f=false|title=Good Music for a Free People: The Germania Musical Society in Nineteenth-century America|publisher=University Rochester Press|year=2010|author=Newman, Nancy|page=40}}Burrows & Wallace, p.724 ==Opera House == Fry engaged the Sanquerico and Patti Opera Company under the management of John Sefton to perform the first season of opera at the house. The opera house opened on November 22, 1847 with a performance of [[Giuseppe Verdi]]'s ''[[Ernani]]'' with Adelino Vietti in the title role.Ireland, p.515 Sefton and his company were not re-engaged by Fry, and the opera management of the house went to Cesare Lietti for the second season. During his tenure the opera house presented the United States premiere of Verdi's ''[[Nabucco]]'' on April 4, 1848.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vEYA8_RARL0C&pg=PA81&dq=%22Boston+Theatre%22+%22Max+Maretzek%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDsQ6AEwBjgKahUKEwjipKjEuPLGAhUN4oAKHYjAAUA#v=onepage&q=%22Boston%20Theatre%22%20%22Max%20Maretzek%22&f=false|title=Verdi in America: Oberto Through Rigoletto|author=Martin, George Whitney|publisher=University Rochester Press|year=2011|page=17}} Lietti was also replaced after one season, and the Astor's third and longest lasting opera manager, [[Max Maretzek]], was hired for the third season which commenced in November 1848.Ireland, pp.515-543 The following year Maretzek founded his own opera company, the [[Max Maretzek Italian Opera Company]], with whom he continued to stage operas at the Astor Opera House through 1852.{{cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/11/23/89147004.pdf|title=Even the Prima Donna Blushed'|author=[[Harold C. Schonberg|Schonberg, Harold C.]]|page=D19|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 23, 1969}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sEE5f70qvUQC&pg=PA35&dq=%22astor%22+%22ernani%22+%221847%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEwQ6AEwCWoVChMIzerJwKP0xgIVlzKICh3HwweE#v=onepage&q=%22astor%22%20%22ernani%22%20%221847%22&f=false|title=Music of the Gilded Age|author1=Ogasapian, John |author2=Orr, N. Lee |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|year=2007|page=35}} Under Maretzek the opera house saw the New York premiere of Donizetti's ''[[Anna Bolena]]'' on January 7, 1850 with soprano Apollonia Bertucca (later Maretzek's wife) as the title heroine.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gMxQrkQTLHYC&pg=PA12&dq=%22Astor%22+%22Maretzek%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAGoVChMIq_Ds5pnwxgIVBMyACh1pag2d#v=onepage&q=%22Italian%20opera%22&f=false|title=Strong on Music: The New York Music Scene in the Days of George Templeton|author=Lawrence, Vera Brodsky|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=1995|page=3}} The theatre was built with the intention of attracting only the "best" patrons, the "[[uppertens]]" of New York society, who were increasingly turning out to see European singers who appeared at local venues such as [[Niblo's Garden]]. It was expected that an opera house would be:
a substitute for a general drawing room – a refined attraction which the ill-mannered would not be likely to frequent, and around which the higher classes might gather, for the easier interchange of courtesies, and for that closer view which aides the candidacy of acquaintance.Nathaniel Parker Willis, quoted in Burrows & Wallace, p.724
In pursuit of this agenda, the theatre was created with the comfort of the upper classes in mind: benches, the normal seating in theatres at the time, were replaced by upholstered seats, available only by subscription, as were the two tiers of boxes. On the other hand, 500 general admission patrons were relegated to the benches of a "cockloft" reachable only by a narrow stairway, and otherwise isolated from the gentry below, and the theatre enforced a dress code which required "freshly shaven faces, evening dress, and kid gloves."Burrows & Wallace, p.760 Limiting the attendance of the lower classes was partly intended to avoid the problems of rowdyism which plagued other theaters in the entertainment district at the time, especially in the theatres on [[the Bowery]]. Nevertheless, it was the deadly [[Astor Place riot]] in 1849 which caused the theatre to close permanently – provoked by competing performances of ''[[Macbeth]]'' by English actor [[William Charles Macready]] at the Opera House (which was operating under the name "Astor Place Theatre", not being able to sustain itself on a full season of opera) and American [[Edwin Forrest]] at the nearby Broadway Theatre. == Clinton Hall == After the riot, the theater was unable to overcome the reputation of being the "Massacre Opera House" at "DisAster Place."Burrows & Wallace, p.765 By May 1853, the interior had been dismantled and the furnishings sold off, with the shell of the building sold for $140,000[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1854/06/01/75368321.pdf "The Mercantile Library"] ''[[New York Times]]'' (June 1, 1854) to the [[New York Mercantile Library]], which renamed the building "Clinton Hall".[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1853/05/27/87854876.pdf "Exclusiveness"] ''[[New York Times]]'' (May 27, 1853) In 1890, in need of additional space, the Association tore down the opera house building and replaced it with an 11-story building, also called Clinton Hall, which still stands on the site.White, Norval & Willensky, p.162 ==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist}} '''Bibliography''' *{{cite gotham}} *{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=354XAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA515&dq=%22astor%22+%22john+sefton%22+%221847%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDIQ6AEwBGoVChMI_oOS_aT0xgIVEzGICh3NGwVp#v=onepage&q=%22astor%22%20%22john%20sefton%22%20%221847%22&f=false|title=Records of the New York Stage: from 1750 to 1860|volume=2|author=Ireland, Joseph Norton|publisher=T. H. Morrell|year=1867}} *{{cite AIA4}} '''Further reading''' *[[John Rose Greene Hassard|Hassard, Jno. [John] R. G.]] (February 1871). [http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015035103277;view=1up;seq=365 "The New York Mercantile Library"], ''Scribner’s Monthly'' Vol. 1 No. 4. New York: Scribner & Co., pp. 353–67 ==External links== *{{commonscat-inline|Astor Place Riot}} [[Category:Opera houses in New York City]] [[Category:Music venues in Manhattan]] [[Category:Defunct buildings and structures in Manhattan]] [[Category:19th century in the United States]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1847]] [[Category:Music venues completed in 1847]] [[Category:Astor family]] [[Category:East Village, Manhattan]] [[Category:1847 establishments in New York (state)]]

revision.text:
'''Bernd Venohr''' (born April 16, 1959 in [[Hanau]], [[Germany]]) is a German [[management consultant]], [[entrepreneur]] and [[author]]. He is the editor of the ''"Lexikon der deutschen Weltmarktführer"'' (Encyclopedia of German world-market leaders)<ref>Florian Langenscheidt, Bernd Venohr (Ed.): ''Lexikon der deutschen Weltmarktführer. Die Königsklasse deutscher Unternehmen in Wort und Bild''. Deutsche Standards Editionen, Köln 2010, {{ISBN|978-3-86936-221-2}}. </ref>about the German [[Mittelstand]] companies.<ref>[http://www.economist.com/node/17572160 "Mittel-management - Germany’s midsized companies have a lot to teach the world"]. The Economist, November 25, 2010.</ref><ref>Uncommon common sense propels Germany’s family companies to become global leaders. FT.com, July 28, 2008.</ref> Between 2006 and 2008 he was a tenured full Professor of [[strategic management]] at the Berlin School of Economics and Law. Before taking up this academic position he spent about 20 years in industry as [[managing director]] at [[Accenture]] and senior partner and member of the worldwide [[board of directors]] at [[Bain & Company]]. Venohr studied [[Administration (business)|business administration]] at the [[Goethe University Frankfurt]], where he also took his Ph.D. degree. In addition, he holds a [[Master of Business Administration]] degree (MBA) from [[Northwestern University]], [[Chicago]]. He is married with two children and lives in [[Munich]].
== Bibliography == * Florian Langenscheidt, Bernd Venohr (Ed.): ''Heilbronn-Franken. Region der Weltmarktführer: Rund 100 Weltmarktführer einer der erfolgreichsten Regionen Deutschlands''. Deutsche Standards Editionen, Köln 2011, {{ISBN|978-3-86936-222-9}}. Portrayal of about 100 world-market leaders in the area of [[Heilbronn-Franken]], [[Germany]]. * Florian Langenscheidt, Bernd Venohr (Ed.): ''Lexikon der deutschen Weltmarktführer (vollständig überarbeitete Neuauflage).'' Deutsche Standards Editionen, Köln 2014, {{ISBN|978-3-86936-656-2}}. Encyclopedia of German world-market leaders. * Florian Langenscheidt, Bernd Venohr (Ed.): ''Lexikon der deutschen Weltmarktführer. Die Königsklasse deutscher Unternehmen in Wort und Bild''. Deutsche Standards Editionen, Köln 2010, {{ISBN|978-3-86936-221-2}}. Encyclopedia of German world-market leaders. * Florian Langenscheidt, Bernd Venohr (Ed.): ''The Best of German Mittelstand - THE WORLD MARKET LEADERS''. DAAB Verlag, Cologne 2015, {{ISBN|978-3-942597-48-7}}. * Bernd Venohr: ''Wachsen wie Würth: Das Geheimnis des Welterfolgs''. Campus Verlag, Frankfurt a.M. 2006, {{ISBN|978-3-593-37962-3}}. Best practise analysis of [[Würth|The Würth Group]]. * Bernd Venohr: ''Marktgesetze und strategische Unternehmensführung. Eine kritische Analyse des PIMS- Programms''. Gabler, Wiesbaden 1988, {{ISBN|978-3-409-13336-4}}.

'''A British Business Group (BBG)''' is an [[Voluntary association|association]] or club of expatriate [[United Kingdom|British]] business people. The aims of the group are typically to encourage trade with the host country and to provide a social environment for [[business network]]ing. Typically a BBG will organize trade missions, lectures and social functions.<ref>[http://www.bbg-jed.org/constitution.html Example constitution, Jeddah BBG, Saudi Arabia] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030809220617/http://www.bbg-jed.org/constitution.html |date=August 9, 2003 }}</ref> Many BBGs fulfill a charitable role, although that is not a primary function.
BBGs are often closely associated with the local British consulate or embassy, and with related organizations, such as [[the Middle East Association]] <ref>[http://www.the-mea.co.uk/ [[The Middle East Association]]<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> or the [[Departments of the United Kingdom Government|UKTI]].<ref>[https://www.uktradeinvest.gov.uk/ UK Trade & Investment: International Business, Exporting from the UK, Investing in the UK<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070623040852/https://www.uktradeinvest.gov.uk/ |date=2007-06-23 }}</ref>
== List of Typical British Business Groups == * United States <ref>[http://www.britishbusinessconnection.com/ British Business Connection] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091212000443/http://www.britishbusinessconnection.com/ |date=December 12, 2009 }}, britishbusinessconnection.com</ref> * Abu Dhabi<ref>[http://www.britishbusiness.org/ Abu Dhabi British Business Group], britishbusiness.org.</ref> * Bangladesh<ref>[http://www.bbg.org.bd/ Bangladesh British Business Group], bbg.org.bd.</ref> * [[British Business Group Dubai & Northern Emirates|Dubai & Northern Emirates]] * Greece, British and Commonwealth Business and Professional Group of Thessaloniki<ref>[http://www.uknet.gr/ British and Commonwealth Business and Professional Group of Thessaloniki, Northern Greece], uknet.gr.</ref> * Jeddah, Saudi Arabia<ref>[http://www.bbg-jed.org/ Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, British Business Group], bbg-jed.org.</ref> * Libya<ref>[http://www.britishembassy.gov.uk/servlet/Front?pagename=OpenMarket/Xcelerate/ShowPage&c=Page&cid=1076523458343 Libya British Business Group] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070513013021/http://www.britishembassy.gov.uk/servlet/Front?pagename=OpenMarket%2FXcelerate%2FShowPage&c=Page&cid=1076523458343 |date=May 13, 2007 }}, britishembassy.gov.uk.</ref> * Macedonia<ref>[http://www.bbgm.co.uk/ Macedonia British Business Group], bbgm.co.uk.</ref> * [[Chennai]], India<ref>[http://www.blonnet.com/2002/11/28/stories/2002112801311700.htm The Hindu Business Line : British Business Group launched<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.bbgchennai.org Official BBG Chennai Website by Social Beat]</ref> * Vietnam <ref>http://www.bbgv.org/</ref> * Oman * Bahrain

'''Charles Edward Michael Terry''', [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] (1897 – 13 April 1980) was a Hong Kong businessman. He was an [[unofficial member]] of the [[Executive Council of Hong Kong|Executive Council]] and [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong]].
Terry was an appointed [[unofficial member]] of the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong]] from 1950 to 1959. He was an unofficial member of the [[Executive Council of Hong Kong]] until he was succeeded by [[Richard Charles Lee]] on 28 May 1961.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=41420|page=3778|date=13 June 1958}}</ref> He was the president of the St. Patrick's Society of Hong Kong in 1941. In 1952, he became the founding commissioner of the [[Civil Aid Service]], a civil organisation that assist in a variety of auxiliary emergency roles, and chairman of the [[Hong Kong St. John Ambulance]] in 1963.
He was awarded Officer and Commander of the [[Order of the British Empire]] (OBE and CBE) in 1955 and 1959 respectively for his public services in Hong Kong.<ref>{{London Gazette|supp=y|issue=41727|page=3720|date=13 June 1959}}</ref> In 1963, he was awarded Officer of the [[Order of Saint John (chartered 1888)|Order of the Hospital of St. John of Jerusalem]].<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=42896|page=507|date=15 January 1963}}</ref> He died in Queensland, Australia in April 1980.<ref>[https://www.ancestry.ca/interactive/1904/46452_b294270-00179?pid=21593332&backurl=https://search.ancestry.ca/cgi-bin/sse.dll?indiv%3D1%26dbid%3D1904%26h%3D21593332%26tid%3D%26pid%3D%26usePUB%3Dtrue%26_phsrc%3DOzZ4353%26_phstart%3DsuccessSource&treeid=&personid=&hintid=&usePUB=true&_phsrc=OzZ4353&_phstart=successSource&usePUBJs=true Charles Edward Michael Terry death record]]</ref>

page.title: Child work in indigenous American cultures

revision.comment: /* Child work and indigenous American communities */Journal cites: fix DOI, Added 1 doi to a journal cite
revision.text:
'''[[Child work]]''' covers the application of physical and mental contributions by children towards achieving a personal or communal goal. As a form of [[prosocial behavior]], children's work is often a vital contribution towards community productivity and typically involves non-exploitative [[Motivation#Indigenous education and learning|motivations]] for children's engagement in work activities.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bourdillon|first=Michael|title=Rights and Wrongs of Children's Work|year=2010|publisher=Rutgers University Press|isbn=978-0-8135-4889-0}}</ref> Activities can range from domestic [[household chores]] to participation in family and community endeavors. Inge Bolin notes that children's work can blur the boundaries between [[Informal learning#American indigenous perspective|learning]], play, and work in a form of productive [[Child Integration|interaction between children and adults]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Bolin|first=Inge|title=Growing Up in a Culture of Respect: Child Rearing in Highland Peru|year=2006|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-71298-0}}</ref> Such activities do not have to be mutually exclusive.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Morelli|first=Gilda A.|author2=Barbara Rogoff|author3=Cathy Angelillo|title=Cultural variation in young children's access to work or involvement in specialised child-focused activities|journal=International Journal of Behavioral Development|year=2003|volume=27|issue=3|pages=264–274|doi=10.1080/01650250244000335|url=http://www.tandf.co.uk/journals/pp/01650254.html|accessdate=20 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140524000841/http://www.tandf.co.uk/journals/pp/01650254.html|archivedate=24 May 2014|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Rogoff|first=Barbara |author2=Gilda A. Morelli |author3=Pablo Chavajay|title=Children's Integration in Communities and Segregation from People of Different Ages|journal=Perspectives on Psychological Science|year=2010|volume=5|issue=4|pages=431–440|doi=10.1177/1745691610375558|url=http://pps.sagepub.com|accessdate=20 May 2014}}</ref>
__TOC__
==Child work and indigenous American communities==
Children's work is a valued means of [[Child development of the indigenous peoples of the Americas|learning and child-rearing]] in many [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Indigenous American]] communities. It is seen as eagerly contributing in a collaborative and flexible environment, aimed at the children learning consideration, responsibility, and skills with the guidance and support of adults.<ref>{{cite web|title=Learning by Observing and Pitching In Overview|url=http://www.learningbyobservingandpitchingin.com/icp-overview-english|accessdate=21 May 2014}}</ref> Indigenous American children are motivated to participate in the community because of [[Value (personal and cultural)|cultural values]], for example, everyone does something to participate, and wanting to be an equal member of society.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Pewewardy | first1 = C | year = 2002 | title = Learning styles of American Indian/Alaska Native Students: A review of the literature and implications for practice | url = | journal = Journal of American Indian Education | volume = 41 | issue = | page = 3 }}</ref> The children do not see it as working, but as helping, because they feel responsible for what happens within their communities.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Coppens | first1 = A. D. | last2 = Alcala | first2 = L. | last3 = Mejia-Arauz | first3 = | last4 = Rogoff | first4 = B. | year = 2014 | title = Children's initiative in family household work in Mexico | url = | journal = Human Development | volume = 57 | issue = | pages = 116–130 | doi = 10.1159/000356768}}</ref> As demonstrated by a [[Nahua peoples|Mexican Nahua]] community, children are encouraged to begin child work at the age of two for about 6 to 7 hours a day. They do not need to be convinced to help, but want to be involved in the activity. Child work can be household help, taking care of family members, or helping in community endeavors.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Alcala | first1 = L. | last2 = Rogoff | first2 = B. | last3 = Mejia-Arauz | first3 = R. | last4 = Coppens | first4 = A. D. | last5 = Dexter | first5 = A. L. | year = 2014 | title = Children's initiative in contributions to family work in indigenous-heritage and cosmopolitan communities in Mexico | url = | journal = Human Development | volume = 57 | issue = | pages = 96–115 | doi = 10.1159/000356763 }}</ref>
[[Indigenous American]] children learn functional life skills through real-time [[Observational learning#Indigenous communities of the Americas|observation]] of adults and [[Child Integration|interactive participation]] of these learned skills within the community.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Paradise|first=R.|author2=Rogoff, B. |title=Side by side: Learning through observation and participation|journal=Ethos|year=2009|volume=37|pages=102–138|doi=10.1111/j.1548-1352.2009.01033.x}}</ref> Active contributions to family and community work directly affects children's [[cognitive]] maturity by allowing children agency over their own development.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bourdillon|first=Michael|title=Rights and Wrongs of Children's Work|year=2010|publisher=Rutgers University Press|isbn=978-0-8135-4889-0|pages=134–135}}</ref> This maturity at a younger age allows children to perform, potentially, higher-skilled tasks. For example, younger children have shown initiative by helping strangers to make them feel like a part of the community. Children do this by offering to help strangers or by treating them like family.<ref>Bolin, I. (2006). Growing up in a culture of respect child rearing in highland Peru. Austin: University of Texas Press.</ref> This maturity comes from the community fully incorporating children at a young age and allowing them to participate in everyday tasks.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Maynard | first1 = A | year = 2002 | title = Maynard, A. E.. (2002). Cultural teaching: The development of teaching skills in Maya sibling interactions | url = | journal = Child Development | volume = 73 | issue = 3| pages = 969–982 | doi=10.1111/1467-8624.00450}}</ref> The community trusts their children and treats them as equals, so the children want to engage in the community as much as they can. For example, parents trust their children to translate and negotiate bills with people, when the parents cannot speak the language.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Reynolds | first1 = J. F. | last2 = Orellana | first2 = M. F. | year = 2009 | title = New immigrant youth interpreting in white public space | url = | journal = American Anthropologist | volume = 111 | issue = 2| pages = 211–223 | doi = 10.1111/j.1548-1433.2009.01114.x }}</ref>
For example, the maturity that indigenous American children develop is demonstrated in Zinacantec [[Maya peoples|Mayan]] communities, where children learn complex motor skills and techniques for weaving through keen observation of working adults and by executing the skills themselves.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Maynard|first=A. |author2=Greenfield, P. |author3=Childs, C.|title=Culture, history, biology, and body: Native and non-native acquisition of technical skill|journal=Ethos|year=1999|volume=27|issue=3|pages=379–402|doi=10.1525/eth.1999.27.3.379}}</ref> Also, in [[Peru]], young Chillihuani boys learn how to build shelters and homes by actively assisting adults during the building process by moving and placing appropriate size stones.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bolin|first=Inge|title=Growing Up in a Culture of Respect: Child Rearing in Highland Peru|year=2006|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-71298-0|pages=63–67}}</ref> Ethnographic studies show that Indigenous American children learn intently through keen observation in activities by other children.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Silva|first=Katie |author2=Correa-Chavez, M. |author3=Rogoff, B.|title=Mexican-Heritage children's attention and learning from interactions directed to others.|journal=Child Development|date=2010|volume=81|pages=898–912|url=http://www.learningbyobservingandpitchingin.com/intent-community-participation-facets/means-of-learning-1/silvacorrearogoff2010|accessdate=2014-05-22|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8624.2010.01441.x|pmid=20573112}}</ref>
Children's work is also attributed to learning [[Moral development#Morality and culture|cultural values]] in addition to individual personality development. Many Indigenous children in [[Peru]] develop a sense of responsibility by participating in work often motivated by an internal and external drive to be an active participant in the community.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ames|first=P.|title=Learning to be responsible: Young children transitions outside school|journal=Learning, Culture, and Social Interaction|year=2013|volume=2|pages=143–154|doi=10.1016/j.lcsi.2013.04.002}}</ref> Paradise & De Haan refer to this process as practicing responsibility and reciprocity through role-taking as an observing helper or active performer.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Paradise|first=R.|author2=De Haan, M.|title=Responsibility and reciprocity: Social organization of Mazahua learning practices|journal=Anthropology & Education Quarterly|year=2009|volume=40|issue=2|pages=187–204|doi=10.1111/j.1548-1492.2009.01035.x}}</ref> Through participation in work, most children in Indigenous American communities identify as cooperative members of a community through first-hand exposure to the direct impact of their action or inaction in community responsibilities.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ames|first=P.|title=Learning to be responsible: Young children transitions outside school|journal=Learning, Culture, and Social Interaction|year=2013|volume=2|pages=143–154|doi=10.1016/j.lcsi.2013.04.002}}</ref> In [[San Pedro La Laguna|Guatemalan Mayan communities]], children are often expected to take part in these practices. When schools became prevalent, children who were not seen as providing valuable contributions to family and community endeavors may only then be sent away to school to make use of their time.<ref>{{cite book|last=Rogoff|first=Barbara|title=Developing Destinies: A Mayan Midwife and Town|year=2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York, NY|isbn=978-0-19-531990-3|page=6}}</ref>
Some indigenous communities are skeptical of sending their children to [[Western Schools|western schools]], because their children lose the initiative to help their families and are not as motivated. Western schooling is a different way of teaching than indigenous communities teach their children.<ref>Lynn,S. (2007). Transborder Lives: Indigenous Oaxacans in Mexico, California, and Oregon. Duke University Press, 2007. {{ISBN|978-0822339908}}</ref> However, children that go through western schooling learn English and end up translating for their families, which is another way of helping them or another way of learning. The children perfect their English and Spanish, as well as their social skills because they interact with many types of people by translating for their families.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Reynolds | first1 = J. F. | last2 = Orellana | first2 = M. F. | year = 2009 | title = New immigrant youth interpreting in white public space | url = | journal = American Anthropologist | volume = 111 | issue = 2| pages = 211–223 | doi = 10.1111/j.1548-1433.2009.01114.x }}</ref>
===Learning by Observing and Pitching In===
The initiative that indigenous children demonstrate is part of the process of [[Learning by Observing and Pitching In]]. LOPI is a seven faceted process of learning commonly used by [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous American]] cultures. It fully immerses a child into the community and allows them to learn, through observation and participation, as they help within their family.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Rogoff | first1 = B | year = 2014 | title = Learning by observing and pitching in to family and community endeavors: An orientation | url = | journal = Human Development | volume = 57 | issue = | pages = 69–81 | doi = 10.1159/000356757 }}</ref> Children learn through their work, which is a cultural tradition among indigenous people. Child work is a social experience that allows a child to gain a sense of responsibility and build ties among the community.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Paradise | first1 = R. | last2 = Rogoff | first2 = B. | year = 2009 | title = Side by side: Learning by observing and pitching in. | url = | journal = Ethos Journal of the Society for Psychological Anthropology | volume = 37 | issue = 1| pages = 102–138 | doi = 10.1111/j.1548-1352.2009.01033.x }}</ref>
==International Labour Organization recognition of child work vs. child labour==
The [[International Labour Organization]] recognizes the importance of child work in various cultures. In most Indigenous communities, work is a source of pride for both adults and children. Because of different cultural views involving labor, the [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO) developed a series of culturally sensitive mandates including Conventions No. 169, 107, 138, and 182 to protect indigenous culture, traditions, and identities. Conventions No. 138 and 182 lead in the fight against child labour, while No. 107 and 169 promote the right of indigenous and tribal peoples and protect their right to define their own developmental priorities.<ref>{{cite book|last=Larsen|first=P.B.|title=Indigenous and tribal children: assessing child labour and education challenges.|publisher=International Programme on the Elimination of Child Labour (IPEC), International Labour Office.}}</ref> The [[ILO]] recognizes these changes are necessary to respect the culture and traditions of other communities while also looking after the welfare of children. In many Indigenous communities, [[parenting]] includes teaching children learn important life lessons through the act of work and through participation in daily life.
Working is seen as a learning process preparing children for the tasks they will have to do as an adult.<ref>{{cite book|title=Guidelines for Combating Child Labour Among Indigenous Peoples|year=2006|publisher=International Labour Organization|location=Geneva|isbn=92-2-118748-9|url=http://www.ilo.org/publns}}</ref> It is a belief that the family's and child’s well-being and survival is a shared responsibility between members of the whole family. They also see work as an intrinsic part of their child's developmental process. While these attitudes toward child work remain, many children and parents from indigenous communities still highly value education.<ref>{{cite book|last=Larsen|first=P.B.|title=Indigenous and tribal children: assessing child labour and education challenges.|publisher=International Programme on the Elimination of Child Labour (IPEC), International Labour Office.}}</ref> ILO wants to include these communities in the fight against exploitative child labor while being sensitive to their traditions and values.
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Child labour]]

{{About|transforming publicly owned or municipal organizations into business [[corporation]]s|the economic and social ideology with a similar name|Corporatism}} {{Economic systems sidebar |Transition}}
'''Corporatization''' is the process of transforming state assets, government agencies, or [[municipally owned corporation|municipal]] organizations into [[corporation]]s.<ref name="GrossiReichard" /><ref name=":0" /><ref name="Voornetal18">{{cite web|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/09540962.2018.1527533|title=Debate: Corporatization as more than a recent crisis-driven development|last=Voorn, Bart, Sandra Van Thiel, and Marieke van Genugten (2018)|publisher=Public Money & Management}}</ref><ref name="Ferryetal" /> It refers to a restructuring of government and public organizations into their administration.<ref name=":0">{{cite web | url=http://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/coporatization.asp#axzz2JheT95Nm | title= Corporatization| author=Investopedia | date= | work= | publisher= | accessdate= 2 February 2013}}</ref> The result of corporatization is the creation of [[State enterprise|state-owned corporations]] (or corporations at other government levels, such as [[municipally owned corporation]]s) where the government retains a majority ownership of the corporation's stock.<ref name="GrossiReichard" /><ref name="Marra">{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Alessandro_Marra2/publication/4732914_Internal_Regulation_by_Mixed_Enterprises_The_Case_of_the_Italian_Water_Sector/links/0deec529a2526c7663000000/Internal-Regulation-by-Mixed-Enterprises-The-Case-of-the-Italian-Water-Sector.pdf|title=Internal regulation by mixed enterprises: the case of the Italian water sector|last=Marra, Alessandro (2007)|publisher=Annals of Public and Cooperative Economics}}</ref>
In contrast, the term may also refer to the construction of [[state corporatism]], where state-owned corporations are created and delegated public joint-stock, publicly listed companies, in order to introduce corporate and [[Outline of business management|business management]] techniques to social tasks resembling [[corporate nationalism]] as an alternative to privatization.<sup>[''[[Wikipedia:Citation needed|citation needed]]'']</sup> Corporatization can also refer to non-corporate entities like universities or hospitals becoming corporations, or taking up management structures or other features and behaviors employed by corporations.<sup>[''[[Wikipedia:Citation needed|citation needed]]'']</sup>
==History== The move towards [[neoliberalism|neoliberal]] economic reform and [[New Public Management]] public service reform in the 1980s led to privatization of public functions in many countries.<ref name="Hood">{{cite web|url=https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/2807/1401574fd01fb00345dcba852f216a825e37.pdf|title=The “New Public Management” in the 1980s: variations on a theme|last=Hood, Christopher (1995)|publisher=Accounting, Organizations and Society}}</ref> Corporatization was seen as a half-way house on the road to privatization.<ref name="GrossiReichard" /> These [[state-owned enterprise]]s are organized in the same manner as private corporations, with the difference that the company's shares remain in the ownership of the state and are not traded on the [[stock market]].<ref name="Marra" /> Corporatization is today often seen as an end in itself in order to introduce autonomy in organizations, hoping that this brings efficiency gains.<ref name="Voornetal">{{cite web|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/03003930.2017.1319360|title=The efficiency and effectiveness of municipally owned corporations: A systematic review|last=Voorn, Bart, Marieke L. Van Genugten, and Sandra Van Thiel (2017)|publisher=Local Government Studies}}</ref>
Some argue that the trend towards corporatization has sped up due to the financial crisis,<ref name="Ferryetal">{{cite web|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/09540962.2018.1486629|title=New development: Corporatization of local authorities in England in the wake of austerity 2010–2016|last=Ferry, Laurence, Rhys Andrews, Chris Skelcher, and Piotr Wegorowski (2018)|publisher=Public Money & Management}}</ref> although there is evidence that there has been a trend towards corporatization since at least the start of the century.<ref name="Voornetal18" />
== Reasons and effects == Corporatization can be used to improve efficiency of public service delivery (with mixed successes), as a step towards (partial) privatization, or to alleviate fiscal stress.
=== (Potentially) improving efficiency === A key purpose of corporatization is externalization.<ref name="GrossiReichard">{{cite web|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/14719030802264275|title=Municipal corporatization in Germany and Italy|last=Grossi, Giuseppe, and Christoph Reichard (2008)|publisher=Public Management Review}}</ref> The effect of corporatization has been to convert state departments (or municipal services) into public companies and interpose commercial boards of [[board of directors|directors]] between the shareholding ministers / city council and the management of the enterprises.<ref name="Marra" /> Such externalization creates legal and managerial autonomy from politicians, which could potentially increase efficiency, as it safeguards the firm from political exploitation. However, corporatization can also fail to bring efficiency (or cause inefficiency), because this autonomy reduces the government's ability to monitor its management. Whether corporatization is beneficial may depend on the nature of the service that is corporatized, where autonomy may be less beneficial for more politicized and complex services.<ref name="Voornetal" />
=== Step towards privatization or hybridization === Although corporatization is to be distinguished from privatization (the former involves publicly owned corporations, the latter privately owned ones), once a service has been corporatised it is often relatively easy to privatise or part-privatise it, for example by selling some or all of the company's shares via the stock market.<ref name="Marra" /> In some cases (e.g. the Netherlands in regard to water supply) there are laws to prevent this.<sup>[''[[Wikipedia:Citation needed|citation needed]]'']</sup> Corporatization also can be a step towards the creation of hybrid forms of organization, such as institutional [[public-private partnership]]s or inter-municipal service organizations.<ref name="Voornetal" />
=== Alleviate fiscal stress === Corporatization is also a means to alleviate fiscal stress, as corporations can become standalone organizations that do not count towards municipalities' budgets.<ref name = "GrossiReichard" /><ref name="Voornetal18" /><ref name="Ferryetal" /><ref name="Citronietal">{{cite web|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/03003930.2012.707615|title=Remapping the state: inter-municipal cooperation through corporatization and public-private governance structures|last=Citroni, Giulio, Andrea Lippi, and Stefania Profeti (2013)|publisher=Local Government Studies}}</ref><ref name="Tavares">{{cite web|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/03003930.2017.1356723|title=Ten years after: revisiting the determinants of the adoption of municipal corporations for local service delivery|last=Antonio Tavares (2017)|publisher=Local Government Studies}}</ref>
== Prevalence == Corporatization of state enterprises and collectively owned enterprises was a major component of the [[economic restructuring]] program of formerly communist nations, most notably the People's Republic of China.<ref name=":1" /> China's contemporary [[socialist market economy]] is based on a corporatized [[state sector]] where state companies are owned by the central government but managed in a semi-autonomous fashion.<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=http://www.worldbank.org/html/prddr/trans/n&d95/china.htm|title=Reform of China's State-owned Enterprises A Progress Report of Oxford Analytica|author=World Bank|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604023901/http://www.worldbank.org/html/prddr/trans/n%26d95/china.htm|archivedate=2011-06-04|accessdate=1 February 2013|df=}}</ref> Corporatization has also been used in [[New Zealand]]{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} and most states of [[Australia]]{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} in the reform of their [[electricity market]]s, as well as in many{{vague|date=March 2016}} other countries and industries (e.g. Dutch water supply companies{{citation needed|date=March 2016}}).
==Major areas== === National level === On a national scale, major areas of services which have been corporatized in the past include:<sup>[''[[Wikipedia:Citation needed|citation needed]]'']</sup> * '''National railroads''', the initial impetus to corporatization of functions that had belonged to national and local governing bodies began in the sphere of national [[railroad]] construction in the mid-19th century. * '''Corporatized highways''', for example [[toll roads]]. * '''Corporatized electricity''' * '''Telecommunications'''
=== Local level === On a local scale, major areas of services which have been corporatized include:<ref name="Voornetal" /><ref name="Voornetal18b">{{cite web|url= https://www.researchgate.net/publication/327833751_Background_Autonomy_Steering_and_Corporate_Governance_Determinants_of_the_Effectiveness_of_Governance_of_Municipal_Corporations|title= Background, Autonomy, Steering, and Corporate Governance: Determinants of the Effectiveness of (Governance of) Municipal Corporations|last=Voorn, Bart, Marieke van Genugten, and Sandra van Thiel (2018)|publisher=Lausanne: EGPA}}</ref> * '''Corporatized water''', for example, the Dutch water supply companies are publicly owned corporations (mostly by municipalities, but also by regional governments). For involvement of private corporations in water supply, see [[water industry]] and [[water privatization]]. * '''Bus services''' * '''Refuse collection''' *'''Housing development''' *'''State employment services''' *'''Theaters and cultural institutions''' See also [[Municipally owned corporation]].
== Further reading == * Citroni, G., Lippi, A., & Profeti, S. (2013). [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/03003930.2012.707615 Remapping the state: inter-municipal cooperation through corporatization and public-private governance structures]. Local Government Studies, 39(2), 208-234. * Ferry, L., Andrews, R., Skelcher, C., & Wegorowski, P. [https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/09540962.2018.1486629 New development: Corporatization of local authorities in England in the wake of austerity 2010–2016]. Public Money & Management, 38(6), 477-480. * Grossi, G., & Reichard, C. (2008). [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/14719030802264275 Municipal corporatization in Germany and Italy]. Public Management Review, 10(5), 597-617. * Tavares, A., & Camoes, P.J. (2007). [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/03003930701417544 Local service delivery choices in Portugal: A political transaction costs network]. Local Government Studies, 33(4), 535-553. * Voorn, B., Van Genugten, M.L., & Van Thiel, S. (2017). [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/03003930.2017.1319360 The efficiency and effectiveness of municipally owned corporations: a systematic review]. Local Government Studies, 43(5), 820-841. * Voorn, B., Van Thiel, S., & Van Genugten, M.L. (2018). [https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/09540962.2018.1527533 Corporatization as more than a recent crisis-driven development]. Public Money & Management, 38(7), 481-482.
==See also== {{Div col|colwidth=25em}} * [[Corporatism]] * [[Corporation]] * [[Corporate capitalism]] * [[Liberalization]] * [[Marketization]] * [[Municipal corporation]] * [[Municipally owned corporation]] * [[Nationalization]] * [[Neoliberalism]] * [[Outsourcing]] * [[Public ownership]] * [[Publicly traded company]] * [[Privatization]] * [[Socialist market economy]] * [[State capitalism]] * [[State-owned enterprise]] {{Div col end}}
'''Examples:''' * [[New Zealand Electricity Market]]
==References== {{reflist}} * Transnational Institute, [http://www.tni.org/books/yearbook2005.htm''Public Services Yearbook 2005/6: Beyond the Market. The Future of Public Services''] * [[Ben Manski]] and John E. Peck, [http://www.libertytreefdr.org/event.php?event_id=90''Corporatization in the US: An Internal Clash of Civilizations''] * Maude Barlow and Tony Clarke, ''Blue Gold: The Fight to Stop the Corporate Theft of the World's Water'' 2002. * Sozzani, Joseph, [https://web.archive.org/web/20061110184425/http://www.bond.edu.au/law/blr/vol13-1/Sozzani.pdf ''Privatization in the United States and Australia: A Comparative Analysis of the Modern Privatisation Movement in Corrections'']

revision.text:
A '''cost-plus-incentive fee''' ('''CPIF''') contract is a cost-reimbursement [[contract]] that provides for an initially negotiated fee to be adjusted later by a formula based on the relationship of total allowable costs to total target costs.<ref name="US"> "Subpart 16.3—Cost-Reimbursement Contracts", U.S. [[Federal Acquisition Regulations]], July 2010, webpage: [https://www.acquisition.gov/far/html/Subpart%2016_3.html F3]. </ref>
Like a [[cost-plus contract]], the price paid by the buyer to the seller changes in relation to costs, in order to reduce the risks assumed by the contractor (seller). Unlike a cost-plus contract, the cost in excess of the target cost is only partially paid according to a Buyer/Seller ratio, so the seller's profit decreases when exceeding the target cost. Similarly, the seller's profit increases when actual costs are below the target cost defined in the contract.
==Formula and Examples== Incentive contracts allow sharing of the risks between the contractor and the client. The contractor is reimbursed all its justifiable costs in addition to a calculated fee. The basic elements of a CPIF contract are: :*'''Target Cost''': the estimated total contract costs. :*'''Actual Cost''': constitutes the reasonable costs that the contractor can prove he has made. :*'''Target Fee''': the basic fee to be paid if the Target Cost matches the Actual Cost (target profit). The Target Fee varies between the Minimum Fee and the Maximum Fee according to a formula tied to the Actual Cost (e.g. Target Fee could be 10% of the Actual Cost). :*'''Sharing Ratio''': the agreed upon cost sharing proportion, normally expressed in percentage (e.g. 85% for the client / 15% for the contractor). It is often different for cost overruns and cost underruns. Other components of incentive fee contracting include: :*'''Maximum Fee''': the highest fee that may be earned, usually expressed as a percentage. :*'''Minimum Fee''': the lowest fee that may be earned, usually expressed as a percentage.
The Final Fee (profit of the contractor) is expressed as follows: Final Fee = Target Fee + (Target Cost - Actual Cost) * Contractor Share<ref>In the formula, an asterisk ("*") is used for multiplication.</ref><ref>[http://www.emeraldinsight.com/journals.htm?articleid=1642103&show=abstract Badenfelt, Ulrika. "The selection of sharing ratios in target cost contracts." Engineering, Construction and Architectural Management 15.1 (2008): 54-65]</ref>
The Final Price of the contract is expressed as follows: Final Price = Actual Cost + Final Fee
Note that if Contractor Share = 1, the contract is a Fixed Price Contract; if Contractor Share = 0, the contract is a cost plus fixed fee (CPFF) contract.<ref>[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0263786394900450 Stephen Ward, Chris Chapman, Choosing contractor payment terms, International Journal of Project Management, Volume 12, Issue 4, November 1994, Pages 216-221, ISSN 0263-7863, 10.1016/0263-7863(94)90045-0]</ref>
For example, assume a CPIF with: :*Target Cost = 1,000 :*Target Fee = 100 :*Benefit/Cost Sharing Ratio for cost overruns = 80% Client / 20% Contractor :*Benefit/Cost Sharing Ratio for cost underruns = 60% Client / 40% Contractor
If the Actual Cost is higher than the Target Cost, say 1,100, the client will pay: 1,100 + 100 + (1,000 - 1,100) * 0.2 = 1,180 (contractor earns 80).
If the Actual Cost is lower than the Target Cost, say 900, the client will pay: 900 + 100 + (1,000 - 900) * 0.4 = 1,040 (contractor earns 140).
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cost-Plus-Incentive Fee}} [[Category:Contract law]] [[Category:Procurement]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} '''Dejan Ristanović''' ({{lang-sr-cyr|italic=yes|Дејан Ристановић}}), is a well known [[Serbs|Serbian]] writer and computer publicist.
In January 1981 he wrote the first article on personal computers for the popular science magazine ''[[Galaksija (magazine)|Galaksija]]'' (Galaxy). During the following years he wrote many articles about programmable [[calculator]]s and [[home computer]]s.
[[Image:DejanR.jpg|thumb|Dejan Ristanović with the computers from the 1980s]]
In December 1983 he wrote a special edition of ''Galaksija'' called "Computers in Your Home" (''[[Računari u vašoj kući]]''), the first computer magazine in former [[Yugoslavia]]. This issue featured entire schematic diagrams guides on how to build computer [[Galaksija (computer)|Galaksija]], created by [[Voja Antonić]].
The series of special editions was eventually developed into computer magazine ''Računari'' (Computers). Ristanović was a contributor of ''Računari'' for 11 years. After that, in 1995 Ristanović founded the PC Press publishing company and magazine ''PC'', the first privately owned computer magazine in [[Serbia]]. Ristanović has been the editor-in-chief of ''PC'' for more than 10 years.
In 1989 he co-founded [[Sezam|Sezam BBS]], which eventually become a major [[Bulletin board system|BBS]] system and evolved to Internet provider [[Sezam Pro]],<ref>[http://www.sezampro.rs Sezam Pro Internet provider]</ref> which in 2009 merged in Orion Telecom.<ref>[http://www.oriontelekom.rs Orion Telecom]</ref>
Dejan Ristanović is the author of about 20 books and more than 500 magazine articles about computers, written in the [[Serbian language|Serbian]] and English languages. He also operates the www.ti59.com nostalgia home page of [[TI-59]] programmable [[calculator]]s.
Dejan Ristanović is alumnus<ref>[http://mg.edu.rs/sr/alumni/spisak-bivsih-ucenika List of MGB Alumni], with divisions, departments, and graduation dates.</ref> of [[Mathematical Gymnasium Belgrade]], graduated in 1981 (search term in the list: "Ристановић Дејан").
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.ristanovic.com Dejan Ristanović's home page] {{en icon}} * [http://www.dejanristanovic.com/ Dejan Ristanovic's home page] {{sr icon}} * [http://www.dejanristanovic.com/refer/ List of publications] * [http://www.ti59.com TI-59 page] * [http://www.sezampro.rs Sezam Pro Internet provider] * [http://www.oriontelekom.rs Orion Telecom] * [http://www.mg.edu.rs Mathematical Gymnasium Belgrade]

{{Infobox person | image = | caption = | birth_date = 1903 | birth_place = [[Port Washington, New York]] |birth_name = Donald Sigmund Stralem | other_names = | death_date = {{death year and age|1987-|1903}} | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = United states | education = B.A. [[Harvard University]] | occupation = Businessman | known_for = Founder of Stralem and Company | religion = | networth = | children = Lynn Stralem | spouse = Jean Lehman Ickelheimer | parents = Edithe Alice Neustadt Stralem
Casimir Ignace Stralem | family = | website = }} '''Donald Sigmund Stralem''' (1903-1976) was an American [[investment banker]] and philanthropist. Stralem worked as a partner in [[Hallgarten & Company]] and then served as chairman of Stralem and Company, an international investment bank that he founded in 1967. He also co-founded the [[North Shore-LIJ Health System|North Shore Hospital]] in [[Manhasset, New York]].{{cite news | newspaper=The New York Times | title=Donald Stralem, A Philanthropist; Investment Banker Headed Travelers Aid Association | date=3 February 1976}} ==Early life and education== Stralem was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family,[http://media.americanjewisharchives.org/docs/concise/s.pdf American Jewish Archives] retrieved October 30, 2015 in [[Port Washington, New York]] on [[Long Island]] on June 28, 1903 to Casimir Ignace Stralem and Edithe Alice (Neustadt) Stralem (his father had changed the family surname from ''Strahlheim'' to ''Stralem'' in 1901).[https://books.google.com/books?id=dxuxAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA1808&lpg=PA1808&dq=Casimir+Ignace+Stralem&source=bl&ots=YY4RFQ1dvj&sig=b0yq708q6v1XH_shJ7UOor18zxc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCMQ6AEwAWoVChMIjuOPh7jtyAIVjDk-Ch2v4gzM#v=onepage&q=Casimir%20Ignace%20Stralem&f=false Laws of the State of New York, Volume 2] retrieved October 30, 2015 He graduated from the [[Morristown-Beard School|Morristown School]] in [[Morristown, New Jersey]] (now the Morristown-Beard School) in 1920. Stralem then completed his bachelor's degree at [[Harvard University]] in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]] in 1924. While at Harvard, Stralem participated in the Morristown School Club, an affinity group at the university.{{cite book | title=The Harvard University Register, Volume 47 | year=1921 | editor=Harvard University}} He later served on the Committee of Overseers for the [[Fogg Art Museum]] at Harvard. Stralem did his graduate studies at the [[Trinity College, Cambridge|Trinity College]] at the [[University of Cambridge]] in [[Cambridge, England]]. ==Travelers aid work== Stralem worked as a leading figure in the travelers aid movement. He served as president of the [[Travelers Aid Society of New York]] (TASNY) for six years {{cite news | newspaper=The New York Times | title=O'Dwyer concedes budget is 'shock'; He Tells Travelers Aid Group Funds Are Needed, in Part, to Keep City 'Friendly' | date=6 April 1946}} and then served as its vice president. Stralem served as president of the National Travelers Aid Association {{cite news | newspaper=The New York Times | title=Setting for Party of Travelers Aid Is Top of the Fair | date=16 October 1963}} and chaired their 1950 biennial convention.{{cite news | newspaper=The New York Times | title=To Head 1950 Convention of the Travelers Aid | date=17 February 1950}} Recognizing the impact of his philanthropy on the local area, New York City named him as an honorary deputy commissioner of the [[New York City Fire Department|Fire Department]].{{cite book | title=The National Cyclopedia of American Biography: Current volume | publisher=J.T. White}} ==Philanthropy== Stralem served a president of the [[United Service Organizations]] Fund of New York.{{cite journal | journal=Harvard Alumni Bulletin | volume=60 | year=1957}} He also served as president and chairman of the George Junior Republic Association (GJRA) and as a member of the advisory board of the [[Girl Scouts of America]]'s New York chapter. GJRA provided citizenship training for children.{{cite news | newspaper=The New York Times | title=Expansion Mapped by Junior Republic | date=15 August 1949}} ==Board service== Stralem served on the [[Board of Directors]] of film production corporations, including [[Columbia Pictures]] Corporation and [[Screen Gems]]. He chaired the Finance Committee of Sony Pictures' Board. Stralem also served on the Board of Directors of [[telecommunication]] companies (e.g., [[Continental Telephone Company]], [[Independent telephone company]]) and industrial companies (e.g., Atlantic Gulf Petroleum, [[United States Leather Company]], Stahl-Meyer) ==Family== Stralem married Jean Lehman Ickelheimer, a member of the [[Lehman family]] that ran the [[Lehman Brothers]] investment bank, on April 11, 1928.[https://www.nytimes.com/1994/12/22/obituaries/jean-stralem-86-philanthropist-known-for-work-with-the-blind.html New York Times: "Jean Stralem, 86, Philanthropist Known for Work With the Blind" by WOLFGANG SAXON] December 22, 1994{{cite book | title=Who's who in Finance and Industry | year=1973 | publisher=Marquis Who's Who}} They had one daughter, Lynn Stralem. Jean Stralem owned an extensive private art collection, which featured works by [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Henri-Émile-Benoît Matisse]], [[Edgar Degas]], and [[Pierre-Auguste Renoir]]. She also collected rare first-edition children's books and miniature furniture. Paralleling her husband's philanthropy, Jean Stralem served on the Board of Directors of the [[American Theatre Wing]] and [[Lighthouse International]] in New York City. She served as vice president of Lighthouse International in 1973 and then as vice chairman.{{cite news | newspaper=The New York Times | title=Jean Stralem, 86, Philanthropist Known for Work With the Blind | first=Wolfgang | last=Saxon | date=22 December 1994}} Jean Stralem also served as a vice chairman of [[Seeing Eye]]'s 1938 fundraising campaign.{{cite news | newspaper=The New York Times | title=Seeing Eye Campaign Will Open Tomorrow. | date=17 October 1938}} ==Athletics== Stralem competed in tennis against other investment bankers. He was a finalist in the 1951 tournament held by the Bond Club of New York, an association of [[Wall Street]] executives.{{cite news | newspaper=The New York Times | title=Wall Street Moves in on Sleepy Hollow; Bond Club Holds Annual Field Day with Golf, Tennis, and Harness Racing | date=9 June 1951}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stralem, Donald}} [[Category:American investment bankers]] [[Category:Philanthropists from New York (state)]] [[Category:Jewish American philanthropists]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:People from Port Washington, New York]] [[Category:1903 births]] [[Category:1976 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:Lehman family]] [[Category:Morristown-Beard School alumni]]

{{refimprove|date=December 2011}} '''Down payment''' (or '''downpayment''', also called a '''deposit''' in British English), is a payment used in the context of the purchase of expensive items such as a [[car]] and a [[house]], whereby the payment is the initial upfront portion of the total amount due and it is usually given in cash at the time of finalizing the transaction. A [[loan]] or the amount in [[cash]] is then required to make the full payment.
The main purposes of a down payment are to ensure that the lending institution has enough capital to create money for a loan in [[fractional reserve banking]] systems and to recover some of the balance due on the loan in the event that the borrower [[default (finance)|defaults]]. In [[real estate]], the asset is used as [[collateral (finance)|collateral]] in order to secure the loan against default. If the borrower fails to repay the loan, the lender is legally entitled to sell the asset and retain a portion of the proceeds sufficient to cover the remaining balance on the loan, including fees and interest added. A down payment in this case reduces the lender's risk to less than the value of the collateral, making it more likely that the lender will recover the full amount in the event of default.
The size of the down payment thus determines the extent to which the lender is protected against the various factors that might reduce the value of the collateral, as well as lost profits between the time of the last payment and the eventual sale of the collateral.
Furthermore, making a down payment demonstrates that the borrower is able to raise a certain amount of money for long-term investment, which the lender may desire as evidence that the borrower's finances are sound, and that the borrower is not borrowing beyond his or her means.
If the borrower is unable to pay off the loan in its entirety, the down payment amount is forfeited.
==Amounts== In the [[United States]], down payments for home purchases typically vary between 3.5% and 20% of the purchase price.<ref>[http://www.hud.gov/buying/loans.cfm "HUD"]</ref> The Federal Housing Administration has advocated lower down payments since its inception in 1934, and, currently, borrowers that qualify for an FHA loan pay only 3.5% for a down payment. With rising home prices in the years from 2000 to 2007, lenders were willing to accept smaller or no down payment (either through 100% financing, seller-assisted down payment assistance, government down payment providers or by providing a combination of an 80% first and 20% second [[mortgage loan|mortgages]]) so that more individuals could purchase homes as their primary residences. Currently, in the United States, the Department of Veterans Affairs offers complete financing for qualifying veterans. The USDA Home Loan program also offers complete mortgage loans with no down payment. These loans are available as direct or guaranteed loans and are offered to qualifying borrowers purchasing a home in a more rural area. Most state finance housing agencies offer down payment assistance. In 2013, the agencies offer a program that provides assistance to qualifying homebuyers of up to three percent of the loan amount. The money from the state housing agencies can be used for down payment or closing costs.
There is more risk for lenders when individuals purchase a home as an investment property. Therefore, the lender may charge a higher interest rate and expect a higher down payment.
==See also== * [[Foreclosure]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Contract law]] [[Category:Personal finance]]
