{{Infobox person | name = Dunbar Wright Bostwick | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = January 10, 1908 | birth_place = [[Manhattan]], [[New York (state)|New York]],
[[United States]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2006|1|25|1908|1|10}} | death_place = [[Shelburne, Vermont|Shelburne, Vermont, United States]] | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | education = [[St. Paul's School (Concord, New Hampshire)]] , [[Yale University]] | occupation = Polo player, Racehorse owner/breeder/trainer/driver | known_for = | party = | spouse = Electra Webb | children = 4 | relations = Siblings:
[[Dorothy Stokes Bostwick|Dorothy Stokes]] (1899–2001)
[[Albert C. Bostwick Jr.|Albert C. Jr.]] (1901–1980)
[[Lillian Bostwick Phipps|Lillian Stokes]] (1906–1987)
[[Pete Bostwick|George H. "Pete"]] (1909–1982) }} '''Dunbar Wright Bostwick''' (January 10, 1908 – January 25, 2006) was an American businessman, hockey player, pilot and horseman. ==Biography== Dunbar Bostwick was the fourth child of [[Albert Carlton Bostwick Sr.]] and Mary Lillian Stokes. His father was a prominent New York automobile and yacht racer. His grandfather, [[Jabez A. Bostwick]], was a partner of [[John D. Rockefeller]] and a founder and treasurer of the [[Standard Oil Trust]].https://www.nytimes.com/1921/11/05/archives/29264181-to-heirs-of-mrs-bostwick-widow-of-the-standard-oil-man.html He attended St. Paul's School (Concord, New Hampshire) and Yale University. During his time at Yale, he served as co-captain of the famous 1932 hockey team and declined an invitation to play in the [[1932 Winter Olympics]] in Lake Placid. In 1932, Bostwick married Electra Webb, a great-granddaughter of [[Cornelius Vanderbilt]], and daughter of [[James Watson Webb, Sr.]] and [[Electra Havemeyer Webb]]. The couple had four daughters and spent their time primarily between New York, NY, Old Westbury, NY, Shelburne, VT and Aiken, SC. ==Military service== During World War II, Bostwick served in [[London|London, England]] with the [[United States Army Air Corps|U.S. Army Air Corps]]. He returned as a Lieutenant Colonel with a [[Bronze Star]] and a Belgian [[Croix de Guerre]] for his help in the organization of the [[Normandy Invasion]] in 1944. ==Polo career== Bostwick's siblings included [[Dorothy Stokes Bostwick]], [[Albert C. Bostwick, Jr.]], [[Lillian Bostwick Phipps]] and [[Pete Bostwick]]. Like his siblings, Bostwick was a competitive horseman, who competed in polo and [[Harness racing]] events all over the country. He earned a 6-goal polo handicap and played for the Aiken Knights and the Bostwick Field polo teams during the 1930s.http://www.bostock.net/tree/bostgen/wnames/d/dunbar1907neww109.html During this time, Bostwick created Bostwick Field with his siblings [[Pete Bostwick]] and [[Lillian Bostwick Phipps]]. During the [[Great Depression]], the Bostwicks believed that everyone should be able to watch polo without being overcharged, which inspired Bostwick Field. The slogan of the field was "Polo for the Populace." ==Harness Racing career== After he gave up polo in the 1940s, Bostwick turned to harness racing. He bred, trained and raced many successful [[Standardbred]] [[Horse gait#trot|trotters]] from his Bostwick Stables in [[Shelburne, Vermont]]. When his most famous horse, [[Chris Spencer (horse)|Chris Spencer]], went lame, Bostwick swam the horse twice a day in [[Lake Champlain]]. Eventually, the horse was back in racing condition and went on to win important races including the 1949 [[American Trotting Championship]] and [[Golden West Trot]] and the 1950 [[Roosevelt Trot]]. Chris Spencer was inducted into the United States Harness Racing Hall of Fame in 1979.[https://www.harnessmuseum.com/content/chris-spencer Harness Racing Museum & Hall of Fame bio for Chris Spencer] Retrieved December 19, 2016 Chris Spencer was also the first horse to fly on an airplane, from Vermont to California to win the Hollywood Stakes race in 1952. Bostwick was a member of the [[Harness Racing Museum & Hall of Fame|United States Harness Racing Hall of Fame]] and founded the Saratoga Harness Racing Association and the Aiken Mile Track. Throughout his life, Bostwick was engaged in multiple business ventures. He invented the magnetic snap barrier, an early gate that preceded current moving gates used at modern horse racetracks. Additionally, he served on the boards of the Aviation Instrument Manufacturing Corporation and Helio Aircraft Corporation, among others.https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/28/sports/othersports/28BOSTWICK.html Dunbar Bostwick died in 2006 at age 98 at his home in Shelburne, Vermont.[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/28/sports/othersports/dunbar-w-bostwick-harness-racing-innovator-dies-at-98.html New York Times January 28, 2006 article titled "Dunbar W. Bostwick, Harness Racing Innovator, Dies at 98] Retrieved December 19, 2016 == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.horseshoes.com/advice/daniels/tmhdrlcl.htm] - 'The Man Had Real Class' * [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/28/sports/othersports/28BOSTWICK.html] - Dunbar Bostwick Obituary * [http://www.bostock.net/tree/bostgen/wnames/d/dunbar1907neww109.html] - News Clippings * [http://wikimapia.org/1870574/Dunbar-Bostwick-Estate] - Dunbar Bostwick Estate * [http://xwebapp.ustrotting.com/absolutenm/templates/?a=37253&z=56] - USTA: Champlain Chris {{DEFAULTSORT:Bostwick, Dunbar}} [[Category:1908 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:American ice hockey forwards]] [[Category:Bostwick family]] [[Category:Ice hockey people from New Hampshire]] [[Category:Yale Bulldogs men's ice hockey players]] [[Category:American racehorse owners and breeders]] [[Category:United States Harness Racing Hall of Fame inductees]] [[Category:United States Army officers]] [[Category:Recipients of the Croix de guerre (Belgium)]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Concord, New Hampshire]] [[Category:Sportspeople from New York City]]

[[Orrin H. Ingram II]] (great-grandson)
[[John R. Ingram (businessman)|John R. Ingram]] (great-grandson) | box_width = }} '''Erskine B. Ingram''' (September 29, 1866 – January 18, 1954) was an American heir, lumber baron, and philanthropist. ==Early life== Erskine B. Ingram was born on September 29, 1866 in [[Eau Claire, Wisconsin]].{{cite news|title=Erskine Ingram, Son of Pioneer Lumberman, Dies |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/19059818/?terms=%22Erskine%2BB.%2BIngram%22 |newspaper=The Daily Telegram |date=18 January 1954|page=1|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = July 5, 2015 }} {{Open access}} His father, [[Orrin Henry Ingram]], was a lumber baron.{{cite news|title=Lumber Heir Dies |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/10099388/?terms=%22Erskine%2BB.%2BIngram%22 |newspaper=Janesville Daily Gazette |date=19 January 1954|page=12|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = July 5, 2015 }} {{Open access}}{{cite news|title=A Lumber Magnate Dies |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/82431733/?terms=%22Erskine%2BB.%2BIngram%22 |newspaper=The Kansas City Times |date=19 January 1954|page=6|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = July 5, 2015 }} {{Open access}} His mother was Cornelia Pierce Ingram. His uncle, [[Julius Ingram]], was a member of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]]. His paternal great-grandfather, David Ingram, immigrated from [[Leeds]], England.[https://www.forbes.com/forbes/1999/0906/6405194s2.html Ingram Chronicles], ''Forbes'', 9/06/1999 ==Career== Ingram inherited his father's concerns in the lumber industry. He served as the Chairman of Investment Securities and Ingram Products Company. He served on the Board of Directors of the Union National Bank of Eau Claire, of which his father had served as President.{{cite news|title=Statement of the Condition of the Union National Bank of Eau Claire at the close of business Dec 13, 1919 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/16476032/?terms=%22Erskine%2BB.%2BIngram%22 |newspaper=Eau Claire Leader |date=8 January 1920|page=10|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = July 5, 2015 }} {{Open access}} Additionally, he was a co-founder of the New Dells Lumber Company with Pearl Chambers, J. E. Hosford and Judge James Wickham, and served as its President. ==Philanthropy== Ingram served on the Board of Advisors of the [[Salvation Army]] and on the Board of Directors of the [[Young Men's Christian Association]] (YMCA). He was a member of the [[Kiwanis]]. ==Personal life== Ingram married Harriet Louise Coggshall Ingram. They attended the First Congregational Church of Eau Claire.{{cite news|title=Ingram Estate May Be Church Home for Aged |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/19055964/?terms=%22Erskine%2BB.%2BIngram%22 |newspaper=The Daily Telegram |date=18 February 1955|page=1|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = July 5, 2015 }} {{Open access}} Their estate in Eau Claire was heavily burned by a [[rubbish fire]] at a local city dump in 1953.{{cite news|title=Unexpected Rubbish Fire at City Dump Blamed for Disastrous Blaze |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/19096767/?terms=%22Erskine%2BB.%2BIngram%22 |newspaper=The Daily Telegram |date=23 April 1953|page=3|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = July 6, 2015 }} {{Open access}} They had a son, [[Orrin Henry Ingram, Sr.]], named after Erskine's father. ==Death== He died on January 18, 1954 in Eau Claire. He was eighty-two years old. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ingram, Erskine B.}} [[Category:1866 births]] [[Category:1954 deaths]] [[Category:People from Eau Claire, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Businesspeople in timber]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Wisconsin]] [[Category:American company founders]] [[Category:American corporate directors]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:American Congregationalists]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:Ingram family]]

Fawzi al-Kharafi | image = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = Kuwait | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Kuwait City]], Kuwait | citizenship = Kuwaiti | education = | occupation = CEO and vice chairman of the [[M. A. Kharafi & Sons]] | known_for = | networth = [[United States dollar|US$]] 1.25 [[1,000,000,000 (number)|billion]] (January 2016) | spouse = married | children = | parents = Mohammed Abdul Mohsen Al-Kharafi | relations = [[Nasser Al-Kharafi]] (brother)
[[Jassem Al-Kharafi]] (brother)
[[Faiza Al-Kharafi]] (sister) | website = {{URL|www.makharafi.net}} }} '''Fawzi al-Kharafi''' ({{lang-ar|فوزي الخرافي}}) is a Kuwaiti [[billionaire]], the CEO and vice chairman of the [[M. A. Kharafi & Sons]]. He is the son of Mohammed Abdul Mohsen Al-Kharafi, the founder of M. A. Kharafi & Sons. As of January 2016, ''[[Forbes]]'' estimated his net worth at US$1.25 billion.{{cite web|title=Fawzi Al-Kharafi|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/fawzi-al-kharafi/|website=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=21 January 2016}} He is married and lives in [[Kuwait City]], Kuwait. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kharafi, Fawzi}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Kuwaiti billionaires]] [[Category:Kuwaiti businesspeople]] [[Category:21st-century Kuwaiti businesspeople]]

revision.comment: Since the 2012 presidential election was close, I wouldn't say an Obama loss would have been an "upset." I changed the language to reflect this.
revision.text:
'''Fred Davis III''' (born c. 1952<ref name="Barabak">{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/aug/21/nation/la-na-fred-davis-20120821|title=Ad man Fred Davis: From 'demon sheep' to a deep hole|author=Mark Z. Barabak|date=August 21, 2012|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=January 11, 2014}}</ref>) is a [[Republican Party (United States)|U.S. Republican Party]] [[media consultant|strategy and media consultant]] who is best known for creating political campaign ads for candidates.
Davis is the oldest of four children. Davis was 19 when his father died; he inherited his father's [[public relations]] firm and left college.<ref name="Barabak" /> In the late 1970s and early '80s, Davis was majority partner in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]] advertising agency Davis & Nauser (with partner Jeffery Nauser), where his client list included just one political candidate, his uncle, then Tulsa mayoral candidate and current U.S. Senator [[Jim Inhofe]] (R, Oklahoma).
Davis left for California when Oklahoma's economy suffered from the collapse of the local oil industry.<ref name="Barabak" /> He founded and leads Strategic Perception, an advertising firm based in [[Hollywood]].<ref name="Lapowsky">{{cite news|url=http://www.inc.com/issie-lapowsky/fred-davis-gop-most-notorious-ad-man.html|title=What You Can Learn from the GOP's Most Feared Ad Man|author=Issie Lapowsky|date=August 21, 2012|work=[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]|accessdate=January 11, 2014}}</ref>
==Work== He created the ''Celebrity'' ad for presidential candidate [[John McCain]] and the ''[[Demon Sheep]]'' video for California Senate candidate [[Carly Fiorina]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Scherer|first=Michael|url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1960405,00.html|title=The Mastermind of Carly Fiorina's Demon-Sheep Ad|publisher=TIME|date= 2010-02-05|accessdate=2010-02-05}}</ref> Davis was described as "the most creative person in the business" by Republican media consultant Mark McKinnon.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/public/article_print/SB122031187392488747.html |title=McCain Team Scrambles to Rescript Show |date= |accessdate=2010-11-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100412035936/http://online.wsj.com/public/article_print/SB122031187392488747.html |archivedate=April 12, 2010 }}</ref> His political clients have included [[George W. Bush|President George W. Bush]], presidential candidates [[Dan Quayle]], [[John McCain]], [[Jon Huntsman Jr.|Jon Huntsman]] and [[John Kasich]]. Senators [[Jim Inhofe]], [[John Cornyn]], [[Lamar Alexander]], [[John McCain]], [[Jeff Flake]], [[Bob Corker]], [[Chuck Grassley]], [[David Perdue]], John Kennedy, [[Ben Sasse]], [[Elizabeth Dole]] and [[Paul Coverdell]]. Also governors [[Sonny Perdue]], [[Rick Snyder]], [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]], and [[Ernie Fletcher]].
His long-shot gubernatorial campaign for [[Sonny Perdue]] in Georgia featured a video of a giant Rat rampaging Georgia. The rat portrayed the current, popular governor [[Roy Barnes]]. The video is credited as starting the movement toward viral videos in politics. Perdue beat Barnes handily, in spite of being outspent more than seven to one.
A similar campaign for now-Governor [[Rick Snyder]] of Michigan featured the unusual Davis slogan, “One Tough Nerd.” The slogan caught on across the state helping propel the unknown Snyder past several statewide office holders into a primary win without a runoff, then the general election.
He created a well-known 2010 ad for [[United States Senate special election in Delaware, 2010|U.S. Senate candidate]] [[Christine O'Donnell]] which featured her declaring she was "not a witch", in response to the re-airing of past statements made by her about her interactions with non-Christian religious practices.<ref name="McGreal2010-09-20">{{cite news|last=McGreal|first=Chris|title=Christine O'Donnell: I dabbled in witchcraft|date=2010-09-20|work=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|location=London|url =https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/sep/20/christine-o-donnell-dabbled-witchcraft|accessdate=2010-09-20}}</ref> O’Donnell’s witch statements had become a staple of late night comedy programs, including Saturday Night Live, before Davis was hired.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/10/09/kristen-wiig-parodies-chr_n_757116.html|title='SNL' Does The Best Parody Of Christine O'Donnell's 'Not A Witch' Ad Yet|work=Huffington Post|last=McGlynn|first=Katia|date=2010-10-10|accessdate=2010-12-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/10/20/elvira-christine-odonnell_n_770527.html|title=Elvira Spoofs Christine O'Donnell's 'I'm Not A Witch' Ad|work= Huffington Post|date=2010-10-20|accessdate=2010-12-03|first=Katla|last=McGlynn}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/10/26/im-not-a-witch-the-remix/|title="I'm Not A Witch" — The Remix|work=The Ca10-2626-10|accessdate=2010-12-03|first=Ashley|last=Parker|date=2010-10-26}}</ref>
In February 2012, Davis authored a controversial ad for Representative [[Pete Hoekstra]] for his Senate campaign against incumbent Democrat [[Debbie Stabenow]]. The ad attacked Stabenow as Debbie "Spend-it-now" and showed an Asian woman riding a bicycle in a rice paddy thanking Stabenow (in broken English) for enriching the Chinese economy at the expense of the U.S.
Republican strategist [[Mike Murphy (political consultant)|Mike Murphy]] tweeted that the ad was "really, really dumb,"<ref name="hill">{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/video/senate/208793-hoekstra-super-bowl-ad-hits-debbie-spend-it-now-on-debt|title=Hoekstra defends ad against charges of racial insensitivity|author=Cameron Joseph|date=February 6, 2012|work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|accessdate=January 11, 2014}}</ref> while Stabenow called it "shocking" and "nasty."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2012/02/offensive-pete-hoekstra-ad-draws-big-bucks-for-rival-sen-debbie-stabenow/|title='Offensive' Pete Hoekstra Ad Draws Big Bucks for Rival Sen. Debbie Stabenow|author=Amy Bingham|date=February 13, 2012|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=January 11, 2014}}</ref> Hoekstra denied that the ad was insensitive to Chinese Americans and was meant to focus on Stabenow's voting record.<ref name="hill" /> Within two weeks, the Hoekstra campaign removed the video from his campaign website and [[YouTube]] account.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/david-catanese/2012/02/hoekstra-scrubs-superbowl-ad-from-sites-115093.html|title=Hoekstra scrubs Super Bowl ad from sites|author=David Catanese|date=February 21, 2014|work=[[Politico]]|accessdate=January 11, 2014}}</ref>
In 2012, Davis’ firm prepared a 57-page plan (commissioned by billionaire [[Joe Ricketts]]) for a $10 million campaign attempting to defeat the re-election of President Obama. It partially recycled points of criticism against Obama from the 2008 presidential campaign, including his relationship with Obama’s reverend, [[Jeremiah Wright]]. The proposal, titled, ''The Defeat of Barack Hussein Obama: The Ricketts Plan to End His Spending for Good,'' was initially approved by the Ricketts' Ending Spending Action Fund.
A copy of the proposal document was released by a person unconnected to the ad campaign to ''[[The New York Times]]'', after which it was roundly lambasted in external commentary. Ricketts then disavowed commissioning the plan. Although Davis' agency had gone at least as far as contacting [[Larry Elder]] to join the project, no ads were ever aired. Ricketts issued a statement disavowing the ad campaign hours after it was publicized by the ''New York Times.''
Other clients of Davis include [[George W. Bush]] and [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]].<ref name="Lapowsky" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Davis, Fred, Iii}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American political consultants]] [[Category:Advertising people]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = George Matthew Adams | birth_name = | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1878|08|23}} | birth_place = [[Saline, Michigan]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1962|10|29|1878|08|23}} | death_place = | occupation = Writer, Businessman | alma_mater = [[Ottawa University]] | known for = George Matthew Adams Newspaper Service }} '''George Matthew Adams''' (August 23, 1878 - October 29, 1962) was an American newspaper columnist and founder of the '''George Matthew Adams Newspaper Service''', which syndicated [[comic strip]]s and columns to newspapers for five decades. His own writings were circulated widely to ''[[The Gettysburg Times]]'' and many other newspapers. == Biography == === Early life and education === Born in [[Saline, Michigan]], George Matthew Adams graduated from [[Ottawa University]] in Kansas. Employed by a Chicago advertising agency, he started operating the elevator and worked his way up to become a copywriter. === George Matthew Adams Newspaper Service === {{Infobox company | name = George Matthew Adams Service | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | former_name = Adams Newspaper Service
Adams Syndication Service | type = | industry = [[Print syndication]] | founded = {{start date and age|1907}} | founder = George Matthew Adams | defunct = {{end date and age|1965|05}} | fate = remaining features sold to [[The Washington Star]], becoming The [[Washington Star Syndicate]] | hq_location = 8 West 40th Street | hq_location_city = [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], N.Y. | hq_location_country = [[United States|U.S.]] | area_served = | key_people = Giordano Bruno Pascale
Harry E. Elmlark | products = Comic strips, newspaper columns, editorial cartoons | brands = | services = | owner = George Matthew Adams | ratio = | rating = | website = }} In 1907, Adams borrowed money to rent and equip an office and launched the '''Adams Newspaper Service'''."George Matthew Adams Started Syndicate on a Shoestring," ''Editor and Publisher'' (Julv 21, 1934). Adams' syndicate was located at 8 West 40th Street in Manhattan. When Adams and ''[[Emporia Gazette]]'' publisher [[William Allen White]] met in [[Chicago]] in 1908, Adams hired White to write about political issues. Adams had copies of Walt Mason's light verse which he had clipped from the ''Gazette'', and said, "I like this stuff. I'd like to syndicate it to other papers. Suppose I could?" White responded, "Sure. Give Uncle Walt about $18 a week, and he'll be tickled pink to do it for you." Adams did, and as Mason's ''Rippling Rhythms'' column increased in popularity, he eventually increased Mason's salary to $15,000 a year.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=T3cyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YbYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5903,5882106&dq=george-matthew-adams+syndicate&hl=en Driscoll, C.B. "New York Day by Day", ''The Palm Beach Post'', July 16, 1939.] {{dead link|date=December 2017}} The name of the Adams Newspaper Service was changed in 1916 to the '''George Matthew Adams Service'''. Writers syndicated by Adams included [[Thornton Burgess]], [[Edgar Guest]] and [[Robert Ripley]]. The syndicate also distributed single-panel cartoons, including some accompanied by jokes, backwoods homilies, light verse or Adams-style inspiration. Adams syndicated comic strips, including [[Billy DeBeck]]'s ''Finn an' Haddie'', [[Percy Crosby]]'s ''The Clancy Kids'', ([[Edwina Dumm]]'s ''[[Cap Stubbs and Tippie]]'', [[Ed Wheelan]]'s ''Minute Movies'', and [[Robert Baldwin (cartoonist)|Robert Baldwin]]'s ''Freddy''. In addition to sports cartoons by [[Lank Leonard]], Adams syndicated [[Johnny Gruelle]]'s illustrated ''[[Raggedy Ann]]'' panels from 1934 to 1938. The uplifting ''Raggedy Ann'' verses emphasized forthrightness, honesty, kindness and thrift. He also syndicated Rebecca McCann's philosophical ''[[The Cheerful Cherub]]''. [[Lloyd Jacquet]] was the syndicate's art director from c. 1936 to 1937,[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=JACQUET%2c+LLOYD Lloyd Jacquet entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. shortly before leaving to found [[Funnies, Inc.]] The syndicate's long-time manager was Giordano Bruno Pascale."Who's Who Among Leading U.S. Syndicate Executives," ''Editor & Publisher'' (September 7, 1946). Archived at [https://strippersguide.blogspot.com/2010/07/news-of-yore-1946-syndicate-executives.html "News of Yore 1946: Syndicate Executives Profiled,"] ''Stripper's Guide'' (July 21, 2010). Adams's syndicate peaked in the 1920s and 1930s, eventually fading as its founder aged. In the company's latter years, the president and general manager was Harry E. Elmlark. Adams died in 1962; the remaining features were sold to The Washington Star Company in May of 1965, thus forming the [[Washington Star Syndicate]].Boyd, Crosby N., President. "THE WASHINGTON STAR HAS PURCHASED THE GEORGE MATTHEW ADAMS SERVICE, A NEWSPAPER FEATURE SYNDICATE," ''The Washington Star'' (May 9, 1965). [https://www.cia.gov/library/readingroom/docs/CIA-RDP73-00475R000100090002-6.pdf Archived at CIA.gov]. === Writing === In the 1910s, Adams was selling Dr. Frank Crane's (1861-1928) popular ''Four Minute Essays''. When he lost Crane to a competitor, he decided to write short inspirational essays himself while he traveled from city to city selling to newspapers. By the 1950s, Crane was all but forgotten, but Adams' short inspirational columns, titled ''Today’s Talk'', were in about 100 newspapers and also collected in a series of books.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GC4iAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6nIFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3991,2754641&dq=george-matthew-adams+frank-tripp&hl=en Tripp, Frank. "About the columners", ''The Day'', May 17, 1954.][http://orlabs.oclc.org/identities/lccn-n88-274966 WorldCat] ====Books==== * ''You Can: A Collection of Brief Talks on the Most Important Topic in the World — Your Success'' (Frederick A. Stokes Company, 1913) * ''Take It: Suggestions as to Your Right to the World and the Great Things That are in It'' (Frederick A. Stokes, 1917) * ''Up: A Little Book of Talks on how to Wake Up, Get Up, Think Up, Climb Up, Smile Up, Cheer Up, Work Up, Look Up, Help Up, Grow Up!'' (Reilly and Lee Company, 1920) * ''Just Among Friends'' ([[William Morrow and Company]], 1928) * ''Better Than Gold'' (Duell, Sloan and Pearce, 1949) * ''The Great Little Things'' (Duel, Sloan and Pearce, 1953) == Adams Service strips and panels == '''Launched in the 1910s''': * ''[[Cap Stubbs and Tippie]]'' by [[Edwina Dumm]] (1918–1965;[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=EDWINA Edwina entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. continued by The Washington Star Syndicate) * ''[[The Cheerful Cherub]]'' by Rebecca McCann (c. 1916–1927) * ''The Clancy Kids'' by [[Percy Crosby]] (1916–c. 1919) * ''Finn an' Haddie'' by [[Billy DeBeck]] (1916) * ''Miss Information'' by Wood Cowan (1919–1922;[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=COWAN%2c+WOOD Wood Cowan entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. moved to the [[Ledger Syndicate]])[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=GAGE%2c+HY Gage entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Nov. 23, 2017. * ''Not Now'' by [[Richard W. Dorgan]] (c. 1916–1917) * ''The Young Lady Across the Way'' by Robert O. Ryder and Harry J. Westerman (1913–1919; moved to [[McClure Newspaper Syndicate]]) * ''Zimmie'' by Arch Bristow (1912–1913) '''Launched in the 1920s''': * ''Billy's Uncle'' by [[Ben Batsford]] (Oct. 9, 1922 - August 2, 1924) * ''In Our Office'' by Wood Cowan (early 1920s) * [[Lank Leonard]] sports cartoons (c. 1927–c. 1936) * ''Minute Movies'' by [[Ed Wheelan]] (1921–1935)[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=WHEELAN%2c+ED Ed Whelan entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. * ''Pecos Bill'' by [[Tex O'Reilly]] and Jack Warren (1929–1938) * ''[[Reg'lar Fellers]]'' ostensibly by [[Gene Byrnes]]; [[Ghostwriter|ghosted]] by Tack Knight (1924-1929;[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=KNIGHT%2c+TACK Tack Knight entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. came over from the [[Bell Syndicate]]; moved to [[King Features Syndicate]]) '''Launched in the 1930s''': * ''[[Alec the Great]]'' by [[Edwina Dumm]] (1931–1965; continued by [[The Washington Star|The Washington Star Syndicate]]) * ''Cap'n Cloud'' by Robert Weinstein (1935)[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=WEINSTEIN%2c+ROBERT Robert Weinstein entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. * ''Decks Awash'' by Augustus J. Robinson (November 16, 1935 – April 4, 1936) * ''Doctor Remedy'' by Adolph Schus (1939) * ''The Enchanted Stone'' by Adolphe Barreaux (1935)[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=BARREAUX%2c+ADOLPHE Adolphe Barreaux entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. * ''Hector Hicks'' by [[Lank Leonard]] (1933) * ''Loco Luke'' by Jack Warren (July 5, 1935 – April 4, 1936)[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=WARREN%2c+JACK Jack Warren entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. * ''[[Raggedy Ann]]'' by [[Johnny Gruelle]] (1934–1938) * ''Ted Strong'' by Al Carreno (1935–1939)[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=CARRENO%2c+AL Al Carreno entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. '''Launched in the 1940s''': * ''Miki'' by Tom Morrison (c. 1945-c. 1950)[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=MORRISON%2c+TOM Tom Morrison entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. '''Launched in the 1950s''': * ''Barkis and Family'' by [[Crockett Johnson]] (1955) * ''Freddy'' by [[Robert Baldwin (cartoonist)|Robert Baldwin]] (1955–1966; continued by [[Publishers-Hall Syndicate]])[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=BALDWIN%2c+ROBERT Robert Baldwin entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. * ''Mr. Holiday'' by Chad Kelly{{cite web|url=http://penandbrush.net/MATERA_bio.html|title=Biography|publisher=Fran Matera official site|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nIgUtLBo?url=http://penandbrush.net/MATERA_bio.html|archivedate=February 4, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} Additional on February 4, 2010. and [[Fran Matera]][http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=MATERA%2c+FRAN Fran Matera entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. (1950–1951) * ''[[Sky Masters of the Space Force]]'' (1958–1961) by [[Jack Kirby]] (1958–1961), [[Marvin Stein]] (1958),[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=STEIN%2c+MARVIN Marvin Stein entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. David Wood,[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=WOOD%2c+DAVID David Wood entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. Dick Wood, & [[Wally Wood]] (1958–1960)[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=WOOD%2c+WALLY Wally Wood entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. '''Launched in the 1960s''': * ''The Birds'' by Joe Appalucci (1963) * ''Buenos Dias'' by Ed Nofziger (1963-1965; continued by The [[Washington Star Syndicate]] 1965-1967)[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=NOFZIGER%2c+ED Ed Nofziger entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928–1999''. Accessed Dec. 4, 2017. * ''Cuppy the Newsboy'' by Joe Appalucci (October 8, 1962 – March 7, 1964) == Adams Service columnists == * George Matthew Adams's ''Today’s Talk'' (c. 1913–c. 1955) * [[Thornton Burgess]]'s ''Bedtime Stories'' (1912–1960) * Dr. [[Frank Crane (writer)|Frank Crane]]'s ''Four Minute Essays'' (c. 1913) * [[Edgar Guest]] (c. 1917–?) * [[Walt Mason]] ("Uncle Walt")'s ''Rippling Rhythms'' (1908–?) * [[Robert Ripley]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://books.google.com/books?id=bVcYAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22george+matthew+adams%22&cd=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''You Can'' by George Matthew Adams] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=aX8XAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22george+matthew+adams%22&cd=2#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''Up'' by George Matthew Adams] * [https://archive.is/20130123174519/http://www.gaia.com/quotes/authors/george_matthew_adams/ George Matthew Adams Quotes] * [http://aaobserver.aadl.org/aaobserver/18633 George Matthew Adams House] * [http://georgematthewadams.blogspot.com/ George Matthew Adams essays] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Adams, George Matthew}} [[Category:1878 births]] [[Category:1962 deaths]] [[Category:American newspaper journalists]] [[Category:People from Saline, Michigan]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:Comic strip syndicates|George Matthews Adams Service]]

The '''Global Industry Classification Standard''' ('''GICS''') is an [[industry taxonomy]] developed in 1999 by [[MSCI]] and [[Standard & Poor's]] (S&P) for use by the global financial community. The GICS structure consists of 11 sectors, 24 industry groups, 68 industries and 157 sub-industries<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msci.com/resources/factsheets/MSCI_Global_Industry_Classification_Standard.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141219200846/http://www.msci.com/resources/factsheets/MSCI_Global_Industry_Classification_Standard.pdf |archivedate=2014-12-19 |df= }}</ref> into which S&P has categorized all major [[public company|public companies]]. The system is similar to ICB ([[Industry Classification Benchmark]]), a classification structure maintained by FTSE Group.
GICS is used as a basis for S&P and [[MSCI]] [[financial market]] indexes in which each company is assigned to a sub-industry, and to a corresponding industry, industry group and sector, according to the definition of its principal business activity. It is also considered to be the most successful as per Finch rating agency.
"GICS" is a [[registered trademark]] of [[McGraw Hill Financial]] and MSCI Inc.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msci.com/products/indices/sector/gics |title=MSCI-Barra GICS Tables |accessdate=2013-02-10 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msci.com/products/indices/sector/gics |title=MSCI-Barra GICS Sector Definitions |accessdate=2013-02-10 |format=PDF }}</ref>

==Revisions== The classification is continuously updated by S&P Dow Jones Indices and MSCI.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msci.com/resources/pdfs/GICS_Consultation2015.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150211031822/http://www.msci.com/resources/pdfs/GICS_Consultation2015.pdf |archivedate=2015-02-11 |df= }}</ref> In November 2014 they proposed to introduce a new sector for real estate, as well as adding a new sub-industry for copper, both to be effective on August 31, 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msci.com/resources/pressreleases/GICS%20Press%20Release%2010%20Nov%202014.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141222181424/http://www.msci.com/resources/pressreleases/GICS%20Press%20Release%2010%20Nov%202014.pdf |archivedate=2014-12-22 |df= }}</ref>

revision.text:
{{About|a means-based model of social welfare|the system of unconditional income provided to every citizen|Basic income|the system where citizens receive an income stream through the public ownership of industry|Social dividend}} '''Guaranteed minimum income''' ('''GMI'''), also called '''minimum income''', is a system<ref>[http://www.basicincome.org/basic-income/history History of Basic Income], ''Basic Income Earth Network (BIEN)'', retrieved on 18 June 2009</ref> of [[social welfare provision]] that guarantees that all [[citizen]]s or [[family|families]] have an income sufficient to live on, provided they meet certain conditions. Eligibility is typically determined by [[citizenship]], a [[means test]], and either availability for the [[labour market]] or a willingness to perform [[community service]]s. The primary goal of a guaranteed minimum income is to [[poverty reduction|reduce poverty]]. If citizenship is the only requirement, the system turns into a [[basic income|universal basic income]].
==Elements== A system of guaranteed minimum income can consist of several elements, most notably:
* a calculation of the social minimum, usually below the [[minimum wage]]; * a [[social safety net]], to help citizens or families without sufficient financial means survive at the social minimum. This may be a transfer or, in some cases, a loan, and is generally conditional to availability for work, performance of community services, some kind of [[social contract]], or commitment to a [[Social integration|reintegration]] trajectory; * [[child support]] by the [[state (polity)|state]]; * [[student loan]] and [[grants]]; * [[state pension]] for the elderly; * [[disability pension]] for the persons with disability.
==Differences from basic income== {{Main|Basic income}}
Basic income means the provision of identical payments from a government to all of its citizens. Guaranteed minimum income is a system of payments (possibly only one) by a government to citizens who fail to meet one or more [[means test]]s. While most modern countries have some form of GMI, a basic income is rare.
==Advocates== The first Muslim [[caliph]], [[Abu Bakr]], introduced a guaranteed minimum standard of income, granting each man, woman, and child ten [[dirhams]] annually; this was later increased to twenty dirhams.<ref>Grace Clark: Pakistan's Zakat and 'Ushr as a Welfare System</ref>
In 1795, American revolutionary [[Thomas Paine]] advocated a [[citizen's dividend]] to all [[United States]] citizens as compensation for "loss of his or her natural inheritance, by the introduction of the system of landed property" (''[[Agrarian Justice]]'', 1795).
French [[Emperor]] [[Napoleon Bonaparte]] echoed Paine's sentiments and commented that 'man is entitled by birthright to a share of the Earth's produce sufficient to fill the needs of his existence' (Herold, 1955).
The [[United States|American]] [[economist]] [[Henry George]] advocated for a dividend to be paid to all citizens from the revenue generated by a [[land value tax]].<ref>{{cite book |last= George|first= Henry|date= 1871|title= Our Land and Land Policy, National and State|url= https://archive.org/details/ourlandandlandp00georgoog|location= |publisher= White & Bauer [etc.]|page= 230|isbn= 9781230444703|author-link= }}</ref>
In 1963, [[Robert Theobald]] published the book ''Free Men and Free Markets'', in which he advocated a ''guaranteed minimum income'' (the origin of the modern version of the phrase).
In 1966, the [[Cloward–Piven strategy]] advocated "overloading" the US welfare system to force its collapse in the hopes that it would be replaced by "a guaranteed annual income and thus an end to poverty".
In his final book ''[[Where Do We Go from Here: Chaos or Community?]]'' (1967), [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] wrote<ref>Martin Luther King jr., ''[[Where Do We Go from Here: Chaos or Community?]]'' (New York: Harper & Row, 1967)</ref> {{"|I am now convinced that the simplest approach will prove to be the most effective—the solution to poverty is to abolish it directly by a now widely discussed measure: the guaranteed income.|from the chapter titled "Where We Are Going"}}
In 1968, [[James Tobin]], [[Paul Samuelson]], [[John Kenneth Galbraith]] and another 1,200 economists signed a document calling for the US Congress to introduce in that year a system of income guarantees and supplements.<ref>''Economists' Statement on Guaranteed Annual Income'', 1/15/1968-4/18/1969 folder, General Correspondence Series, Papers of John Kenneth Galbraith, John F. Kennedy Presidential Library. Cited in: Jyotsna Sreenivasan, [https://books.google.com/books?id=yk5NI69ZO9sC "Poverty and the Government in America: A Historical Encyclopedia."] (Santa Barbara: ABC-CLIO, 2009), page 269</ref>
President Richard Nixon proposed reforms to the welfare program in 1969, where a minimum income would be paid to poor families. Contrary to popular belief, Nixon was critical of the idea of a guaranteed universal basic income. The proposal by Nixon passed in the House but never made it out of committee in the Senate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=2194|title=Richard Nixon: Special Message to the Congress on Reform of the Nation's Welfare System.}}</ref>
In 1973, [[Daniel Patrick Moynihan]] wrote ''The Politics of a Guaranteed Income'', in which he advocated the guaranteed minimum income and discussed [[Richard Nixon]]'s Guaranteed Annual Income (GAI) proposal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=2191|title=Richard Nixon: Address to the Nation on Domestic Programs}}</ref>
In 1987, [[New Zealand]]'s [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour]] Finance Minister [[Roger Douglas]] announced a Guaranteed Minimum Family Income Scheme to accompany a new flat tax. Both were quashed by then Prime Minister [[David Lange]], who sacked Douglas.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940DE5DE133CF937A15751C0A96E948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all "New Zealand Is Jolted By a Speedy Decontrol"], Seth Mydans, ''The New York Times'' (24 February 1988)</ref>
In his 1994 "autobiographical dialog", [[classical liberal]] [[Friedrich Hayek]] stated: "I have always said that I am in favor of a minimum income for every person in the country".<ref>Hayek on Hayek: An Autobiographical Dialogue by F. A. Hayek, edited by Stephen Kresge and Leif Wenar (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1994)</ref>
In 2013, The Equal Life Foundation published the Living Income Guaranteed Proposal<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/182616757/The-Living-Income-Guaranteed-Proposal|title=The Living Income Guaranteed Proposal}}</ref> illustrating a practical way to implement and fund a minimum guaranteed income.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://livingincome.me/wiki/The_Living_Income_Guaranteed_Proposal|title=The Living Income Guaranteed Proposal|work=Living Income Guaranteed}}</ref>
In 2017, Harry A. Shamir (US) published a book "Consumerism, or Capitalism Without Crises" in which the concept was promoted by another label, as a way to enable our civilization to survive in an era of automation and computerization and large scale unemployment. The book also innovates a method to fund the process, tapping into the underground economy and volunteerism.
Other modern advocates include [[Hans-Werner Sinn]] (Germany), [[Ayşe Buğra]] (Turkey), The Green Economics Institute (GEI),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greeneconomics.org.uk|title=Green Economics|publisher=GEI}}</ref> and [[Andrew Coyne]] (Canada).<ref>[http://business.financialpost.com/2013/04/08/a-minimum-income-not-wage-is-a-fairer-way-to-distribute-wealth/ "A minimum income, not wage, is a fairer way to distribute wealth"], Andrew Coyne, ''The Financial Post'' (8 April 2013)</ref>
==Funding== {{refimprove section |date=December 2013}}
Tax revenues would fund the majority of any GMI proposal. As most GMI proposals seek to create an earnings floor close to or above poverty lines amongst all citizens, the fiscal burden would require equally broad tax sources, such as income taxes or VATs, in order to fund such expenditures. To varying degrees, a GMI might be funded through the reduction or elimination of other social security programs such as [[unemployment insurance]].
Another approach for funding is to acknowledge that all modern economies use fiat money and thus taxation is not necessary for funding; However, the fact that there are no financial constraints does not mean other constraints, such as on real resources, do not exist. A likely outcome based on the economic theory known as [[Modern Monetary Theory]] would be a moderate increase in taxation to ensure the extra income would not cause demand-pull inflation; This hypothetical [[Chartalism|Chartalist]] approach can be seen in the implementation of [[quantitative easing]] programs where, in the United States, over three trillion dollars<ref>[https://research.stlouisfed.org/fred2/graph/fredgraph.png?g=2pXx Fredgraph]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y7Xh0hY3-sM&t=0m8s|title=Ben Bernanke: As a Literal Fact the Fed is not Printing Money|first=|last=wonkmonk|date=12 May 2012|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> were created without requiring taxes.
==Examples around the world==
===Cyprus=== In July 2013, the Cypriot government unveiled a plan to reform the welfare system in Cyprus and create a {{'}}''Guaranteed Minimum Income''{{'}} for all citizens.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cyprus-mail.com/2013/07/26/president-announces-guaranteed-minimum-income-for-all-citizens/|title=President announces 'Guaranteed Minimum Income' for all citizens|work=Cyprus Mail}}</ref>
===France=== In 1988, France was one of the first countries to implement a minimum income, called the [[Revenu minimum d'insertion]]. In 2009, it was turned into [[Revenu de solidarité active]] (RSA), a new system which aimed at solving the [[poverty trap]] by providing low-wage workers a complementary income; thus encouraging activity.
===United States=== {{quote box |quote=No business which depends for existence on paying less than living wages to its workers has any right to continue in this country. |source = [[President Franklin Delano Roosevelt]], 1933<ref name="NYT-20140307">{{cite news |last=Tritch |first=Teresa |title=F.D.R. Makes the Case for the Minimum Wage |url=http://takingnote.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/03/07/f-d-r-makes-the-case-for-the-minimum-wage/ |date=March 7, 2014 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=March 7, 2014 }}</ref> | width = 260px }} The [[United States]] has multiple social programs that provide guaranteed minimum incomes for individuals meeting certain criteria such as assets or disability. For instance, [[Supplemental Security Income]] ('''SSI''') is a United States government program that provides [[stipend]]s to low-income people who are either aged (65 or older), blind, or disabled. SSI was created in 1974 to replace federal-state adult assistance programs that served the same purpose. Today the program provides benefits to approximately eight million Americans. Another such program is [[Social Security Disability Insurance]] ('''SSD''' or '''SSDI'''), a [[payroll tax]]-funded, [[Federal Insurance Contributions Act tax|federal insurance]] program. It is managed by the [[Social Security Administration]] and is designed to provide [[income supplement]]s to people who are physically restricted in their ability to be [[employed]] because of a notable [[disability]], usually a [[physical disability]]. SSD can be supplied on either a temporary or permanent basis, usually directly correlated to whether the person's disability is temporary or permanent.
An early guaranteed minimum income program in the U.S. was the [[Aid to Families with Dependent Children]] (AFDC), established by the [[Social Security Act]]. Where previously the responsibility to assist needy children lay in the hands of the states, AFDC transferred that authority to the federal government.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Lurie|first=Irene|date=1997-01-01|title=Temporary Assistance for Needy Families: A Green Light for the States|url=https://academic.oup.com/publius/article/27/2/73/1916654|journal=Publius: The Journal of Federalism|volume=27|issue=2|pages=73–87|doi=10.1093/oxfordjournals.pubjof.a029915|issn=0048-5950}}</ref> Over time, the AFDC was often criticized for creating disincentives to work, leading to many arguing for its replacement. In the 1970s, President [[Richard Nixon|Richard M. Nixon]] proposed the Family Assistance Program (FAP) which would replace the AFDC. FAP was designed to fix many of the problems that the AFDC suffered from, particularly the anti-work structure. Presidential nominee [[George McGovern]] also proposed a minimum income in the form of a Universal Tax Credit. Ultimately, neither of these programs were implemented. Throughout the decade, many other experimental minimum income programs were carried out in cities throughout the country, such as the Seattle-Denver Income Maintenance Experiments.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Larson|first=David|date=January 1, 1992|title=Long Overdue: The Single Guaranteed Minimum Income Program|url=|journal=University of Detroit Mercy Law Review.|volume= 69|pages=353}}</ref> In 1996, under President [[Bill Clinton]], the AFDC was replaced with the [[Temporary Assistance for Needy Families]] program. This would [[block grant]] funds to the states to allow them to decide how aid would be distributed.<ref name=":0" />
Another guaranteed minimum income program in the U.S. is the [[Earned income tax credit|Earned Income Tax Credit.]] This is a refundable tax credit that gives poorer families cash assistance every year. The EITC avoids the [[welfare trap]] by subsidizing income, rather than replacing it.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zelleke|first=Almaz|date=December 2005|title=Basic Income in the United States: Redefining Citizenship in the Liberal State|url=|journal=Review of Social Economy|volume= 63|pages=633–648}}</ref>
=== Brazil === Minimum income has been increasingly accepted by the Brazilian government. In 2004, President [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva|Lula da Silva]] signed into law a bill to establish a universal basic income.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wispelaere|first=Jurgen De|date=October 2016|title=Basic Income in Our Time: Improving Political Prospects Through Policy Learning?|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-social-policy/article/basic-income-in-our-time-improving-political-prospects-through-policy-learning/C69074D813A9FE5096E60718131ACAD6|journal=Journal of Social Policy|volume=45|issue=4|pages=617–634|doi=10.1017/s0047279416000039|issn=0047-2794|via=}}</ref> This law is primarily implemented through the [[Bolsa Família]] program. Under this program, poorer families will receive a direct cash payment via a government issued debit card. Bolsa Família is a [[conditional cash transfer]] program, meaning that beneficiaries will receive their aid if they accomplish certain actions. Families who receive the aid must put their children in school and participate in vaccination programs. If they do not meet these requirements, they will be cut off from aid.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/10650663|title=Happy families|date=2008-02-07|work=The Economist|access-date=2017-11-30|issn=0013-0613}}</ref> As of 2011, approximately 50 million people, or a quarter of Brazil's population, were participating in Bolsa Família.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldbank.org/en/country/brazil/overview#2|title=Overview|work=World Bank|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en}}</ref>
=== Canada === Canada has experimented with minimum income trials, both in the past and in the present. The most prominent past example is the [[Mincome]] experiment, which ran in [[Manitoba]] in the 1970s. Mincome provided lower income families with cash transfers to keep them out of poverty. The researchers conducting Mincome found that it did not disincentivize work. The only recipients who reduced their number of hours worked were single mothers, who could now afford to stay at home and raise their children, and young men who preferred to stay in school rather than work.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://policyoptions.irpp.org/magazines/2001-odyssee-espace/a-guaranteed-annual-income-from-mincome-to-the-millennium/|title=A guaranteed annual income? From moncome to millennium|work=Policy Options|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en-US}}</ref> Budget shortfalls resulted in the shuttering of the program.
In 2017, the province of [[Ontario]] began an minimum income experiment. Approximately 4000 citizens began to receive a stipend based on their family situation and income.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/04/24/pf/canada-ontario-money-basic-income-program/index.html|title=Canada: Ontario launches guaranteed income program for 4,000 residents|last=Petroff|first=Alanna|work=CNNMoney|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref> Recipients of this program can receive upwards of $10,000 per year. Government researchers are using this pilot as a way of testing to see if a minimum income can help people meet their basic needs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ontario.ca/page/ontario-basic-income-pilot|title=Ontario Basic Income Pilot|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ontario.ca|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref>

{{Infobox person |name = Gustaf Larson |image = File:Gustaf Larson 1950-55.jpg |image_size = 250px |caption = Gustav Larson at Volvo AB (1950s). |birth_name = Erik Gustaf Larson |birth_date = {{birth date|1887|7|8|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Vintrosa|Vintrosa, Sweden]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1968|7|4|1887|7|8|df=y}} |death_place = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = [[Sweden|Swedish]] |other_names = |education = |occupation = [[Business]], [[Engineering]] |employer = |known_for = co-founder of [[Volvo]] |home_town = |salary = |height = |weight = |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |boards = |religion = |children = Erik, Anders, Gunnel, and Britt |parents = |relatives = |website = |signature = |footnotes = |networth = |spouse = Elin Octavia Fröberg |partner = }} '''Erik Gustaf Larson''' (8 July 1887 – 4 July 1968) was a Swedish [[automotive engineer]] and the co-founder of [[Volvo]]. He held a Master of Science (M. Sc.) degree in [[Mechanical Engineering]] from the [[Royal Institute of Technology]] in Stockholm.
==Biography== Larson was responsible for the technical design of the first Volvo model [[Volvo ÖV 4|ÖV 4]], introduced on 14 April 1927. He and [[Assar Gabrielsson]] founded Volvo. He was appointed vice president and technical manager for AB [[Volvo]] in Gothenburg, from the time the company was founded 1927. He worked for Volvo until his death in 1968.
==Volvo== [[File:Volvo OV4 Touring 1928.jpg|thumb|300px|1928 [[Volvo ÖV 4]] Touring model.]] [[File:PV4 1.JPG|thumb|300px|c. 1929 Volvo PV4, the covered version of ÖV4.]]
===Invention and development=== In June 1924 when Gustav Larson met his old friend [[Assar Gabrielsson]] in Stockholm, Gabrielsson unveiled his plans to try to establish the manufacturing of a new Swedish automobile. Gustav Larson had worked for SKF between 1917-1919 but now worked for the company AB Galco in Stockholm. They made a verbal agreement in August 1924 at the [[Sturehof]] restaurant in Stockholm, then signed a written contract more than one year later, on 16 December 1925. In this contract Gustav was to carry out the engineering work for a new car, as well as an investment plan for a complete new manufacturing plant, but would only be rewarded for that work in case the project would turn out well. Well meant after at least 100 produced cars and in the case this was achieved before 1 January 1928. This famous contract shows that Assar Gabrielsson "owned" the project and that it was a high-risk project without any guarantees. Gabrielsson took the economic risks himself and Gustav, in the worst case, would have worked on the project without being rewarded, but still would have had his salary from AB Galco in Stockholm. Most of the capital that Gabrielsson intended to use for the project initially was actually extra sales commissions that he had saved from the time he was the [[managing director]] for the SKF subsidiary in [[Paris]] in 1921-22.
Gabrielsson had decided to build a test series of ten vehicles with his own financing and later present the car and an entire investment plan to SKF. The idea to build a pre-series of ten vehicles was most certainly related to the fact that no company would have given he and Larsen an offer for the components (engines, gearboxes, chassis components etc.) With less quantity they were certain that SKF would approve plans in due time. Engineering, documentation and investment planning was carried out exactly in the same way, as if it had been carried out by SKF in order to prepare for the set up of a new automobile company. Gabrielsson most certainly had the full support from the managing director of SKF, Mr. [[Björn Prytz]], at that time, as long as his 'private' project did not interfere with his work as sales manager for SKF.
The first ten pre-series vehicles, model [[Volvo ÖV 4|ÖV 4]], were designed and assembled in Stockholm at AB Galco under the supervision of Gustav Larson, at that time still having his other work at AB Galco to attend to. A "design-office", often called "Volvo's first design-office", was established in one room of Larson's private apartment at [[Rådmansgatan]] 59. The design work started in the autumn of 1924 and a number of engineers were involved, among them engineer [[Jan G. Smith]], that had returned from America in 1924, and later engineer Henry Westerberg. All the invoices related to the project was sent to Gabrielsson's private address at Kungsportsavenyn 32 in Gothenburg. In a lot of orders that Gustav Larsson made himself, he referred to Gabrielsson as a "guarantee" so that the deliveries would be paid by him personally. These details shows that the Volvo automobile project in the beginning was a true private project, not sponsored by SKF from an economic point of view.
The first prototype car was ready in June 1926. Larsen and Gabrielsson took it and drove themselves, on bumpy roads, down to SKF in Gothenburg to show the SKF-board and now present the final investment plan.
===AB Volvo founded === At a board meeting held in [[Hofors]], Sweden on 10 August 1926, SKF decided to use the old subsidiary company Volvo AB, for the automobile project. AB Volvo, that was first registered in 1915 on the initiative of Björn Prytz, was originally set up to be used for a special series of ball bearings for the American market but it was never really used for this purpose. A small series of ball bearings stamped with Volvo was manufactured but it was never introduced on a larger scale.
A contract was signed on 12 August 1926 between SKF and Gabrielsson, stipulating that all ten prototype cars, engineering drawings, calculations etc. should be handed over to Volvo AB, and Gabrielsson in return would be refunded most of his private investments for the prototype cars. The contract was signed by [[Björn Prytz]], managing director of SKF and Gabrielsson. Gustaf Larsson finally got paid for the initial engineering work with the ÖV4 according to the 'private' contract he and Gabrielsson had signed on 16 December 1925. That 1925 contract had stated that the automobile project may be sold to any company that would be interested, but they hoped that SKF would be the company to first offer.
Gustav Larson was appointed vice president and technical manager on 1 January 1927, and left his employment at AB Galco in Stockholm.
=== First production Volvo=== On 14 April 1927, at about 10 p.m., the first series production model, the [[Volvo ÖV 4|ÖV 4]], left the newly established factory on [[Hisingen]] in [[Gothenburg]].
The ten prototype cars that had been assembled in Stockholm were never sold, except for one that was sold to Volvo's photographer Sven Sjöstedt and was later donated to the [[Volvo Museum|Volvo Industrial Museum]] around 1930. However it was used as transportation vehicles within the manufacturing plant and as 'test benches' for new developed components during the first years.
=== Economic problems === The new company did not show any profit for the first couple of years and SKF invested more money to keep the company running. In 1928 the production of [[truck]]s began with the basic chassis components from ÖV4. The production of trucks was on a small scale, but the concept was successful from start.
However, in late 1929 SKF nearly sold the company to [[Charles W. Nash|Charles Nash]], president of [[Nash Motors]] in the [[United States]]. Björn Prytz and Gabrielsson managed to convince the SKF board to call the deal off, just one day before Charles Nash arrived by boat in [[Gothenburg]]. At the end of 1930 AB Volvo showed a small profit for the first time. In 1935 SKF came to the conclusion that Volvo now was ready to stand on its own feet. Volvo was introduced on the [[Stockholm stock exchange]] and SKF sold most of its shares. SKF could now concentrate on their core business, development and manufacturing of bearings, and still are, more than 100 years after the company was founded in 1907.
[[File:Gustav Larson and Assar Gabrielsson in museum of Volvo in Gothenburgh.JPG|thumb|310px|Bronze statue of founders Gustav Larson and [[Assar Gabrielsson]] in the [[Volvo Museum]] in Gothenburg.]]
=== Sales success === In 1941, the 50,000th Volvo car was delivered. It took ten years to produce the first 25,000 cars but only four years for the next 25,000 cars. In 1944-45, just after the end of the [[Second World War]], the modern styled family car [[PV444]], with a completely new design, was introduced and the car was a sales success. The company now stood on solid ground and the production of both cars and trucks continued to increase for the rest of Larsen's life.
==Family== Gustaf Larson was married to Elin Octavia Fröberg in 1918. They had four children: Erik, Anders, Gunnel, and Britt.
Gustaf Larson died on 4 July 1968, and is buried at the family tomb in [[Båstad]], Sweden.

'''Harri Roschier''' (born 1957) [[Helsinki]] is a [[Finland|Finnish]] entrepreneur. Roschier was the CEO for [[Talentum Oyj]], a leading business-to-business media company in the [[Nordic countries]] between 1992 and 2006.<ref>{{cite news | title=Talentum Oyj Chief Executive Officer Resigns | url=https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/keyDevelopments?symbol=TTM1V.HE&pn=3 | newspaper=Reuters | date=28 July 2006 | accessdate=8 July 2011}}</ref> During the Roschier years the company became one of the fastest growing media companies in terms of revenue and market capitalization in the [[Nordic Countries]], growing from a less than €10 million to a €100 million company. After leaving Talentum Roschier joined in 2007 [[Avaus Marketing Innovations|Avaus Consulting]] - a management consultancy, marketing services and technology company. <ref>[http://www.digitoday.fi/tyo-ja-ura/2007/02/12/entiset-alaiset-ottivat-roschierin-osakkaaksi/20073675/66 Kauppalehti 12.2. 2007: Roschier joins his ex-employees in Avaus]</ref> He has also worked as a board member of [[Futurice]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.finder.fi/IT-sovelluksia,%20IT-ohjelmistoja/Futurice%20Oy/HELSINKI/management/248826 |title=Futurice Oy - management - Fonecta Finder |website=Fonecta Finder |publisher=Fonecta Oy |accessdate=January 17, 2014}}</ref>
Until 1980, Roschier competed in [[alpine skiing]], winning several medals in Finnish championships. He won the [[giant slalom]] in 1979<ref>{{cite journal | title=Roschier sai ensimmäisen SM:n suurpujottelussa | journal=Skimbaaja | volume=3 | issue=3 | pages=33 | year=1979}}</ref> and 1980.<ref>{{cite journal | title=Alppilajien SM-kilpailut | journal=Skimbaaja | volume=4 | issue=3 | pages=60 | year=1980}}</ref> In 1982 he went on to become the managing director of the Finnish alpine ski magazine [[Skimbaaja]]<ref>{{cite journal | title=Skimbaaja 1977–1987 | journal=Skimbaaja | volume=11 | issue=7 | pages=64 | year=1987}}</ref> of which he even acted as the editor-in-chief in 1989. After selling the publishing company to [[Sanoma]] Oyj, he worked for some time for the special interest title publishing unit within Sanoma, before becoming the CEO of a public company at 35. Roschier is still an active skier and passionate competitive sailor<ref>{{cite web | title=Volvo Espoo-Suursaari Race 2005 | url=http://www.espoosuursaarirace.org/tulokset/2005/ims1final2005.htm | date=12 June 2005 | accessdate=8 July 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726034843/http://www.espoosuursaarirace.org/tulokset/2005/ims1final2005.htm | archivedate=26 July 2011 | df= }}</ref> in the [[H-boat]] class and with his 45-footer Luna. In 2012 a syndicate headed by Roschier launched Luna a [[8mR]] replica based on drawings by [[Charles E. Nicholson]] from 1936. Luna came second in the 8 metre worlds in 2012 in Cowes.

The '''International Engine of the Year'''{{cite web|title=International Engine of the Year Awards|url=http://www.ukimediaevents.com/engineoftheyear|date=2017|work=UKi Media & Events Ltd.|accessdate=17 March 2017}} is an annual competition for [[automotive industry]] [[internal combustion engine]]s, judged by a panel of [[automobile]] journalists from around the world. It is organised by UKi Media & Events' Automotive Magazines.{{cite web|title=UKi Media Events|url=http://www.ukimediaevents.com|date=2017|work=UKi Media & Events Ltd.|accessdate=17 March 2017}} The competition was started in 1999. page.title: International Young Music Entrepreneur of the Year

revision.text:
The '''International Young Music Entrepreneur of the Year''' award is a [[British Council]] and [[London Calling]] award program for young (aged 25 to 35) entrepreneurs in the music industry from the developing and transitional economies, launched in 2006, and last held in 2009.
The program participants come from all sectors of the music industry - [[music label|label managers]], [[artist manager]]s, [[DJ]]s/[[VJ (media personality)|VJ]]s, [[music festival|festival]] directors, [[music retail]]ers, and others. Chosen by an international jury and following a visit to [[London]], [[Manchester]] and the [[Glastonbury festival]], the winner receives a financial award of £7,500 to be spent on a collaborative project with the British Council.
==IYMEY 2006== The first winner of the IYMEY award was Mohamed 'Momo' Merhari from Morocco, who co-founded the [[Boulevard des Jeunes Musiciens]], the largest [[contemporary music]] festival in North Africa and the first event dedicated to [[urban music|urban]], contemporary and [[underground music]]. Momo was joined by specially commended finalists from India and Indonesia as well as finalists from Argentina, Estonia, Kenya, Lebanon, Poland and Venezuela.
==IYMEY 2007== Finalists for the 2007 edition of the IYMEY award came from Egypt, India, Indonesia, Latvia, Lithuania, Malaysia, Nigeria, Philippines, Poland and Tanzania, and [[Audu Maikori]] who runs [[Chocolate City Music|Chocolate City]], a label, studio and event consultancy in Nigeria was chosen as the winner.
== IYMEY 2008 == Robert Simenya also known as Robert Kamanzi or simply Rkay from East Africa [Kenya] was chosen as the winner in 2008. He runs Moja Entertainment Ltd., which includes artist management, music publishing and distribution, Music video production, a record label, and a recording studio. He is also a board member and the Chairman of the Performers Rights Society of Kenya (PRISK] from 2010 - 2016.
==See also== * [[International Young Publisher of the Year]]
==External links== * [http://www.britishcouncil.org/arts-music-iymey-2006.htm IYMEY 2006] * [http://www.creativeconomy.org.uk/iymey IYMEY 2007] * [http://creativeconomy.britishcouncil.org/people/robert-rkay-kamanzi/ IYMEY 2008]
[[Category:British music awards]] [[Category:Early career awards]] [[Category:Business and industry awards]] [[Category:Awards established in 2006]] [[Category:British Council]]

{{Infobox Newspaper |name = Investor's Business Daily |logo=IBD Logo.png |logo_size=220px |type = Financial research |foundation = 1984 (as ''Investor's Daily'') |owners = Investor's Business Daily, Inc. |founder = William J. O'Neil |editor = |price = USD $1.00 |headquarters = 12655 Beatrice Street
[[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], [[California|CA]] 90066
[[United States]] |ISSN = |website = {{URL|http://www.investors.com}} |}} '''''Investor's Business Daily''''' ('''''IBD''''') is an American newspaper and website covering the stock market, [[international business]], [[finance]] and [[economics]]. Founded in 1984 by [[William O'Neil]] as a print news publication, it is headquartered in [[Los Angeles, California]].{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/investors-business-daily-will-become-a-weekly-1457131255|title=Investor's Business Daily Will Become a Weekly|author=Lukas Alpert |publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=4 March 2016|accessdate=12 April 2016}} Holding a [[conservative]] political stance, ''IBD'' provides news and analysis on [[stock]]s, [[mutual fund]]s, [[exchange-traded fund|ETFs]], [[commodities]], and other financial instruments aimed at individual investors and financial professionals. In March, 2016, the company announced that ''IBD'' would become a weekly publication and would focus more on digital operations.{{cite web|url=http://www.foliomag.com/2016/investors-business-daily-reduces-print-schedule/|title=Investor's Business Daily Reduces Print Schedule|publisher=Folio Magazine|author=Greg Dool |date=7 March 2016 |accessdate=12 April 2016}} The publication will continue to use the ''Investor's Business Daily'' name as it will continue to publish daily on its website.{{cite web|url=http://talkingbiznews.com/1/investors-business-daily-to-become-a-weekly-20-news-jobs-to-be-cut/|title=Investor's Business Daily to Become a Weekly, 20 News Jobs to be Cut|publisher=Talking Biz News|author=Chris Roush |date=4 March 2016 |accessdate=12 April 2016}} In May 2016, the company officially switched to a weekly print publishing schedule and published its first issue of ''IBD Weekly'' while continuing to update its website daily.{{cite web|url=http://talkingbiznews.com/1/explaining-the-changes-at-investors-business-daily/|title=Explaining the Changes at Investor's Business Daily|publisher=Talking Biz News|author=Chris Roush|date=May 9, 2016|access-date=July 7, 2016}} ==History== [[File:Investor's Business Daily (front page).jpg|220px|right]] Entrepreneur and stockbroker [[William O'Neil]] founded the newspaper in 1984 due to frustration with the lack of data about stocks in newspapers. In 1991, the publication's name was changed from ''Investor's Daily'' to ''Investor's Business Daily''.{{cite web|url=https://seekingalpha.com/article/4058903-warren-buffett-influential-investor-time|title=How Warren Buffett Is Not The Most Influential Investor of Our Time|work=Seeking Alpha|date=29 March 2017}} In 1994, ten years after its founding, ''IBD'' was ranked among the fastest-growing newspapers in the country.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-01-20/news/we-13561_1_investor-s-business-daily|title=Media: Financial Paper Closing In on Bottom Line |publisher=Los Angeles Times |author=Greg Krikorian|date=20 January 1994|accessdate=12 April 2016}} In 2005, the political cartoonist [[Michael Ramirez]] joined ''IBD''. In 2008, Ramirez won his second Pulitzer for editorial cartooning while at the company.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/07/business/media/07cnd-pulitzers.html?_r=0|title=Washington Post Wins 6 Pulitzer Prizes|publisher=The New York Times |author=Richard Perez-Pena |date=7 April 2008|accessdate=12 April 2016}} In 2015, the ''IBD'' website was accessed by over 4 million monthly visitors. In 2016, it was announced that the company would change its printing schedule to once a week, but continue to publish new content to its website daily. In May 2016, the first issue of ''IBD Weekly'' was published while the media outlet continued to publish new digital content daily. During the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election in the U.S.]], ''IBD'' was one of two polls that consistently showed [[Donald Trump]] in the lead. Leading up to the election, ''IBD's'' poll was correctly dismissed as being an "outlying survey" and in the end missed the final popular vote tally by four percentage points in Trump's favor.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/bad-polling-in-hand-media-misses-mark-badly-with-election-predictions-1478710860|title=How the Media's Election Predictions Badly Missed the Mark|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|first1=Joe|last1=Flint|first2=Lukas|last2=Alpert|date=November 9, 2016|access-date=November 25, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2016/11/09/how-two-polls-predicted-trumps-surprise-victory.html|title=How Two Polls Predicted Trump's Surprise Victory|publisher=Fox News|date=November 9, 2016|access-date=November 25, 2016}} ==Operations== ''IBD'' takes a conservative political stance in its news and analysis.John Atlas, ''Seeds of Change: The Story of ACORN, America's Most Controversial Antipoverty Community Organizing Group'' (Vanderbilt University Press, 2010), p. 297: "In 2007, ''Investor's Business Daily'', a conservative business newspaper, repeated more misrepresentations."Stephen E. Frantzich, ''The C-SPAN Revolution'' (University of Oklahoma Press, 1996), p. 321:"After years of frustration with what they perceived as the liberal commercial media, conservative sources gloated after the 1994 election. An editorial in ''Investor's Business Daily'' argued..."John K. Wilson, ''Barack Obama: This Improbable Quest'' (Routledge, 2009), p. 209: "The conservative ''Investor's Business Daily'' editorialized..." ''IBD'' provides investor education through its Investor's Corner, the Big Picture, and online resources. The information provided expands on William O'Neil's previous books that detail the [[CAN SLIM]] investment strategy.{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/conversation-with-a-maverick-investor-2011-09-13|title=Conversation With a Maverick Investor|publisher=MarketWatch |author=Kevin Marder |date=13 September 2011 |accessdate=13 April 2016}} ''IBD'' includes several written sections that detail companies and news of interest. It covers internet and technology stocks in particular, and has a substantial editorial and opinion section. Every Monday in its weekly edition, ''IBD'' publishes a list of 50 stocks that are most attractive based on earnings, stock price performance, and other criteria used in the CAN SLIM strategy.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/02/23/oneil-ibd-canslim-personal-finance_william_oneil.html|title=Breaking Out With Bill O'Neill |publisher=Forbes |author=John Dobosz |date=23 February 2009 |accessdate=13 April 2016}} === IBD 50 === '''''The IBD 50 Index''''' is the flagship US stock market benchmark published by the Investor’s Business Daily, similar to how [[FTSE 100 Index|FTSE 100]] was to the [[Financial Times]].{{Cite news|url=https://research.investors.com/stock-lists/ibd-50/|title=Stock Lists 50 {{!}} Investor's Business Daily|work=Investor's Business Daily|access-date=2018-08-18}}{{Cite news|url=https://research.investors.com/stock-charts/nyse-i-b-d-50-index-0ibd5.htm?cht=null&type=daily|title=I B D 50 Index - Stock Investment Research, IBD Stock Charts|work=Investor's Business Daily|access-date=2018-08-18}} The index is based on the CAN SLIM methodology invented by the newspaper’s founder William O’Neil, and the list of its constituents is published every Monday.{{Cite news|url=https://education.investors.com/financial-dictionary/ibd-tools/ibd-rgr--50-index|title=IBD® 50 Index {{!}} Financial Terms Key Terms University|work=Investor's Business Daily|access-date=2018-08-18}} Later it becomes the basis for an [[exchange-traded fund]] (ETF) called the '''Innovator IBD 50 ETF''' (Ticker: FFTY), which is also rebalanced weekly.{{Cite web|url=http://innovatoretfs.com/|title=Innovator ETFs|website=Innovator ETFs|access-date=2018-08-18}} ==Errors and retractions== In July 2009, an editorial in ''Investor's Business Daily'' claimed that physicist [[Stephen Hawking]] "wouldn't have a chance in the U.K., where the [British] [[National Health Service]] (NHS) would say the life of this brilliant man, because of his physical handicaps, is essentially worthless."{{cite web | last = Robertson| first = Lori| authorlink = | coauthors = | title = How to Not Prove a Point| work = FactCheck.org| publisher = Annenberg Public Policy Center| date = August 13, 2009| url = http://www.factcheck.org/2009/08/how-to-not-prove-a-point/| format = | doi = | accessdate = 12 April 2017 }} Hawking was British, lived in the [[United Kingdom]] nearly all of his life, and received his medical care from the NHS. ''IBD'' later removed the editorial's reference to Hawking in its online version and appended an "Editor's Note" which said, "This version corrects the original editorial which implied that physicist Stephen Hawking, a professor at the University of Cambridge, did not live in the UK."{{cite news|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2009/08/12/hawking_british_and_alive/|title=Obama health reform critics face inconvenient truth|date=2009-08-12|accessdate=2014-08-14|publisher=[[The Register]]|last=Metz|first=Cade}}{{cite news | work = [[The Washington Post]] | first = Ezra | last = Klein | title = How Stephen Hawking Proves That Investor's Business Daily's Editorial Page Tells Lies | url = http://voices.washingtonpost.com/ezra-klein/2009/08/how_stehpen_hawking_proves_tha.html | date = August 10, 2009 | accessdate = August 17, 2009}} Hawking himself responded, "I wouldn't be here today if it were not for the NHS. I have received a large amount of high-quality treatment without which I would not have survived."Damien McElroy, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/6017878/Stephen-Hawking-I-would-not-be-alive-without-the-NHS.html Stephen Hawking: I would not be alive without the NHS], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' (August 12, 2009). Retrieved May 29, 2014. ==References== {{reflist|3}} ==External links== {{Portal|Greater Los Angeles|Journalism}} * [http://www.investors.com/ibd-university/ IBD educational resources] * [http://www.investors.com/ibd-videos/ IBD videos] [[Category:American business newspapers]] [[Category:Newspapers published in the Greater Los Angeles Area]] [[Category:Publications established in 1984]] [[Category:Pulitzer Prize-winning newspapers]]

'''Santiago Antonio Clariond Desdier''' (born as '''Jacques Antoine Clariond Desdier''' in [[France]]) was a [[Mexico|Mexican]] businessman.
Clariond founded [[Industrias Monterrey]] (IMSA) in 1936 IMSA made steel and aluminium along with batteries in 2007IMSA sold its steel division to Ternium.He married Maria del Consuelo Garza Gonzalez and had 2 children and 10 grandchildren. He was the grandfather of two [[governors of Nuevo León]]: [[[Benjamín Clariond Reyes-Retana| (son of [[Eugenio Clariond Garza]]) and [[[Fernando Canales Clariond|(son of [[Consuelo Clariond Garza]]).
Wife Maria Consuelo Garza Gonzalez Children Eugenio Clariond Garza 1919 2004 (84)years Maria Consuelo Clariond Garza 1922 2016(94)years Grandchildren Eugenio Ninfa Maria Benjamin Santiago Jose clariond reyes retana from Eugenio Clariond Garza) (From Consuelo Consuelo Fernando ,Susana and Marcelo Canales Clariond) ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081012020716/http://www.grupoimsa.com/XStatic/Default.asp?strPageName=HistorialIMSA&intSiteLanguageId=1 History] {{es icon}} of [[Grupo IMSA]] *[http://www.nobe-ref.org/pdf/Conferences/2001/PANELV_MCERUTTI.PDF ''La economía de la frontera México-Estados Unidos en el siglo XXI''] {{es icon}} ("The economy of the Mexico-United States border in the 21st century")
{{DEFAULTSORT:Clariond, Jacques Antoine}} [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:Mexican businesspeople]] [[Category:Mexican company founders]] [[Category:French emigrants to Mexico]] [[Category:Living people]] {{mexico-business-bio-stub}} {{France-business-bio-stub}}
