revision.text:
'''Liban M. Hussein''' ({{lang-so|Liibaan Xuseen}}, {{lang-ar|لبنان حسين}}) (born in [[Somalia]]) is a [[Canadian citizen|Canadian]] entrepreneur and businessman. He was a stakeholder in the [[Al-Barakat]] money transfer firm. In November 2001, Hussein was arrested at the request of the [[United States]] government, which accused him of supporting terrorism through the company. His assets were also frozen. Hussein was eventually exonerated of the charges and released, after a court found that neither the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] (RCMP) nor the U.S.A authorities were able to provide any evidence of terrorist links.<ref name="pays">[[CanWest]], "Canada: Government pay out of court settlement to falsely accused "terrorist" suspect", October 2, 2003</ref><ref>Fox, [http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,38272,00.html Arrests made throughout US], November 7, 2001</ref> In February 2012, all charges against the Al-Barakat Group of Companies were also dropped.<ref name="UN"/>
==Businesses== Hussein ran two businesses in [[Ottawa]], Ontario. The first was a cleaning company, which he started to offer his family employment and improve their chances of successful immigration to Canada.<ref name="loome">Loome, Jeremy. [[Ottawa Sun]], "Security legislation: a double-edged sword", September 12, 2005</ref> The second was a ''[[hawala]]'', a form of informal money transfer business, named ''Barakaat North America Inc.'' Hussein and his brother ran the latter business out of [[Dorchester, Boston|Dorchester]], [[Massachusetts]].
==Arrest== When it was announced that [[al-Qaeda]] was believed to have ties to the Somali money transfer service, [[Al-Barakat]], which Hussein contracted, his brother was arrested in Boston. The cleaning [[Franchising|franchise]] also revoked Hussein's license.<ref name="loome"/><ref name="counterterrorism">{{cite book |last1=Hocking |first1=Jenny |last2=Lewis |first2=Colleen |date=2007 |title=Counter-terrorism and the Post-democratic State |url=https://books.google.dk/books?id=ItgXW8MQCjAC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing Limited |pages=86–87 |isbn=9781845429171 |access-date=10 March 2015 }}</ref>
[[United States]] listed Al-Barakat as a terrorist entity, along with Hussein and his brother. The [[Canadian government]] also followed suit and labelled Hussein, his brother and their company as terrorists, without conducting its independent investigation. The [[United Nations Security Council]] also listed Hussein as a terrorist and froze all his assets.<ref name="counterterrorism" />
Hussein went to the Ottawa police department, where he was arrested on November 7, 2001 by the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] at the request of the [[United States]] government.<ref name="cbc">[[CBC News|CBC]], "[http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2001/11/12/hawala_arrest011112.html Ottawa man wanted in U.S. arrested by RCMP]", November 12, 2001</ref> A court later released him on bail, as no evidence of terrorist links had been produced.<ref name="counterterrorism" /> Hussein was later represented by lawyer [[Michael Edelson]].<ref name="kerry">Pither, Kerry. "Dark Days: The Story of Four Canadians Tortured in the Name of Fighting Terror", 2008.</ref>
==Exoneration== On June 3, 2002, seven months after Hussein was originally listed as a terrorist, the Canadian government announced that it had been shown "no evidence" suggesting that he was linked to terrorism, and that charges would therefore be dropped.<ref name="justice">[[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]], "[http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/news-nouv/nr-cp/2002/doc_30513.html Canada Halts Extradition Process, Liban Hussein De-Listed] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614042520/http://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/news-nouv/nr-cp/2002/doc_30513.html |date=2011-06-14 }}, June 3, 2002</ref> Hussein's name was subsequently removed from the Canadian list of individuals supporting terrorism, and later off of the American and United Nations lists as well, after the Canadian government sought his de-listing there.<ref>[[Canada Gazette]] Part II, [http://www.gazette.gc.ca/archives/p2/2002/2002-06-04-x/pdf/g2-136x8.pdf Vol. 136, No. 8, Extra] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321012101/http://www.gazette.gc.ca/archives/p2/2002/2002-06-04-x/pdf/g2-136x8.pdf |date=2012-03-21 }}, June 4, 2002</ref>
The Civil Liberties Association of Ottawa was quoted in newspapers that "the government destroyed this man's life without a single shred of evidence".<ref name="pays"/> Hussein subsequently reached a monetary settlement with the Canadian government for an undisclosed amount, and has since remained out of the public eye.<ref name="counterterrorism" /> In February 2012, the charges against Al-Barakat were also dropped, and all 17 entities associated with the Al-Barakat Group of Companies were removed from the UN Security Council al-Qaida Sanctions Committee's list, including the Barakat Bank of Somalia, Al-Barakat Exchange and Barakat Telecommunications Company.<ref name="UN">https://www.un.org/News/Press/docs/2012/sc10549.doc.htm</ref>
==See also== *[[Al-Barakat]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hussein, Liban}} [[Category:Canadian Muslims]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Somalian emigrants to Canada]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Majid Jafar | honorific_prefix = | honorific_suffix = | image = File:Majid Jafar Image.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Majid Jafar addressing the [[Davos]] Annual Meeting of the [[World Economic Forum]] | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1976}} | birth_place = | residence = | nationality = UAE | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = | education = Eton College | alma_mater = Cambridge University
London University (SOAS)
Harvard Business School | employer = | organization = Crescent Petroleum | notable_works = | occupation = Energy sector | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | boards = | spouse = Lynn Barghout Jafar | partner = | children = 2 | parents = | relations = | awards = | website = }} '''Majid Hamid Jafar''' (Arabic مجيد حميد جعفر ), born 1976, is a [[United Arab Emirates|UAE]] businessman of Iraqi origin, the [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Crescent Petroleum]],{{cite web|title=Board Members|url=http://www.crescent.ae/majid-jafar.html|website=Crescent Group|publisher=Crescent Group|accessdate=11 June 2014}} the Middle East's oldest privately-held oil and gas company. He is vice-chairman of the Crescent Group, his family's company, and the managing director of [[Dana Gas]]{{cite web|title=Majid Jafar Managing Director of the Board of Dana Gas|url=http://www.weforum.org/global-agenda-councils/majid-jafar}} (PJSC). In 2014, he was named one of the world's 50 most influential Arabs by ''[[The Middle East in London|Middle East Magazine]]''.{{Cite news|url=http://www.themiddleeastmagazine.com/wp-mideastmag-live/2014/07/our-fifty-most-influential-arabs-2014/|title=OUR FIFTY MOST INFLUENTIAL ARABS 2014 - The Middle East Magazine Online...|date=2014-07-15|work=The Middle East Magazine Online...|access-date=2018-03-18|language=en-US}} ==Early life== Majid Jafar is the eldest son of [[Hamid Jafar]], founder of Crescent Petroleum and chairman of the Crescent Group, and a grandson of [[Dhia Jafar]], a politician and cabinet minister in the last decade of Iraq's monarchy,[https://books.google.com/books?id=TPH53xE6MF4C&pg=PA176&lpg=PA176&dq=Dr.+dhia+jafar+Iraqi+cabinet+minister&source=bl&ots=jCownAV_jO&sig=Dwrzc3ZOc8D8-7-QHm8SQe33YjI&hl=en&ei=8tqFTtejN4qL0AXgpYz8Dw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Dr.%20dhia%20jafar%20Iraqi%20cabinet%20minister&f=false "Independent Iraq"], ''[[I.B.Tauris]]'', UK 1996. Retrieved in 1996. during the reign of [[Faisal II of Iraq|King Faisal II]] until 1958. ==Education== Jafar attended [[Eton College]] and graduated from [[Cambridge University]] ([[Churchill College, Cambridge|Churchill College]]) with bachelor and master's degrees in engineering ([[fluid mechanics]] and [[thermodynamics]]). He holds a master's degree {{Cite news|url=https://www.chathamhouse.org/about/governance/majid-jafar|title=Majid H Jafar|work=Chatham House|access-date=2018-10-22|language=en}} in international studies and diplomacy from the University of London's [[School of Oriental and African Studies]] (SOAS), and an MBA from [[Harvard Business School]].[http://investing.businessweek.com/businessweek/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=33350777&privcapId=13728268&previousCapId=882789&previousTitle=Fortum%20Espoo%20Oyj "Business Profile"], ''[[Bloomberg Business]]'', USA October 2011. Retrieved on October 2011. == Early career == Previous to joining Crescent in 2004, Jafar spent several years working at [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]] with Shell International's Exploration & Production and Gas & Power Divisions in London.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/people/16669954-majid-hamid-jafar|title=Majid Jafar|last=|first=|date=|website=Bloomberg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2016-10-22}} == Oil and gas == Jafar left Shell in 2004 to join Crescent Petroleum{{Cite news|url=http://www.oilreview.me/industry/crescents-wise-man-looks-north|title=Crescent's wise man looks north|last=Watts|first=Ben|date=|work=Oil Review Middle East|access-date=2018-10-23|language=}} at their headquarters in [[Sharjah]], [[United Arab Emirates|UAE]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.ditchley.com/past-events/past-programme/2000-2009/2004/change-in-the-middle-east|title=Political, social and economic change in the Middle East {{!}} Ditchley Foundation|website=www.ditchley.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-23}} He was appointed as the company's CEO in 2011.{{Cite news|url=https://gulfnews.com/business/sharjah-gas-supply-arbitration-next-year-1.830268|title=Sharjah gas supply arbitration next year|last=Editor|first=Saifur Rahman, Business|date=2011-06-30|work=GulfNews|access-date=2018-10-23}} Crescent's business and exploration focus lies in the [[MENA]] region{{Cite news|url=http://gulfbusiness.com/exclusive-majid-jafar-ceo-crescent-petroleum/|title=Exclusive: Majid Jafar, CEO, Crescent Petroleum - Gulf Business|date=2012-11-26|work=Gulf Business|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en-US}} with a special focus on [[Egypt]] and [[Iraq]]/[[Iraqi Kurdistan|Kurdistan]], where the Jafar family originally stems from.{{Cite web|url=https://www.arabianbusiness.com/100-under-40--world-s-most-influential-young-arabs-625956.html|title=100 under 40: The world’s most influential young Arabs - ArabianBusiness.com|website=ArabianBusiness.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-31}} In a 2018 licensing round Crescent Petroleum was awarded new development and production contracts for the Gilabat and Qumar gas fields in Iraq.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iraq-oil-gas/iraq-oil-and-gas-exploration-and-development-contract-auction-starts-idUSKBN1HX19T|title=No oil majors win contracts in Iraq oil licensing round|last=Chmaytelli|first=Maher|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-10-31|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-04-26/iraq-awards-some-oil-and-gas-blocks-as-exxon-and-total-drop-out|title=Iraq Awards Some Oil and Gas Blocks as Exxon and Total Drop Out|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bloomberg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-31}} Jafar has been named as one of the 25 most powerful people in the Middle East oil and gas sector.{{cite web|title=21-30 of the most powerful people in ME Oil & Gas|url=http://www.arabianoilandgas.com/article-10878-21-30-of-the-most-powerful-people-in-me-oil-gas/4/#.UZoy2U7frIU}} He has also been a commentator on the oil and gas sector[http://www.thegulfonline.com/Articles.aspx?ArtID=3744 "Energy resources"], ''Gulf Online'', UAE, May 2011. Retrieved on May 2011. and energy policy[http://gulfnews.com/business/oil-gas/gas-vital-to-middle-east-economies-1.830847/ "Gas Vital to Middle East Economies"], ''[[Gulf News]]'', UAE, July 2011. Retrieved on July 2011. and has written on the economic challenges in the Arab World,[http://www.thenational.ae/thenationalconversation/comment/gcc-investment-can-lead-post-revolution-states-to-stability/ "GCC investment can lead post revolution states to stability"], "[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]", UAE, Sept 2011. Retrieved in December 2011.[http://www.thenational.ae/thenationalconversation/comment/egypts-economy-is-crippled-by-unrest-but-gcc-states-could-offer-vital-help#full "Egypt's economy is crippled by unrest but GCC states could offer vital help"], "[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]", UAE, Feb 2012. Retrieved on 21 February 2012. the development of the UAE[http://www.thenational.ae/thenationalconversation/comment/principles-of-a-nation-offered-an-advantage-from-the-start/ "Principles of a nation offered an advantage from the start"], "[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]", UAE, Dec 2011. Retrieved in December 2011 and the geopolitics of oil and gas in the Caspian Region.[http://library.kimep.kz/amlibweb/webquery.dll?v1=pbMarc&v2=GROWTH%20RATE&v4=7993&v5=3Y&v8=7994&v9=1&v10=N&v11=113469&v13=14C&v20=14&v23=0&v25=Akiner,%20Shirin.&v27=16855&v46=7994 GCC "economic challenges in the Arab World"], ''[[RoutledgeCurzon]]'', London 2006. Retrieved on 2006 In 2013 Jafar was elected Vice-Chairman of the Global Energy Initiative,{{cite web|url=http://www.arabnews.com/news/463479|title=Global Energy Initiative: Key role for Crescent Petroleum CEO|last=|first=|date=4 September 2013|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=17 October 2013|quote=}} He was listed among the top 100 business leaders from the Middle East and was awarded as "Visionary of the Year" at the CEO Middle East Awards in 2013.{{Cite news|url=https://www.zawya.com/mena/en/press-releases/story/Majid_Jafar_named_Visionary_of_the_Year_at_CEO_Middle_East_Awards_-ZAWYA20130912103117/|title=Majid Jafar named 'Visionary of the Year' at CEO Middle East Awards|access-date=2018-11-17|language=en-US}} He was also awarded as Energy CEO of 2013 by Amwal{{cite web|title=List of funds for the 100 most powerful business leaders during the 2013|url=http://www.amwal-mag.com/article/9263/%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%A6%D9%85%D8%A9-%D8%A3%D9%85%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%84-%D9%84%D8%A3%D9%82%D9%88%D9%89-100-%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%A6%D8%AF-%D8%A3%D8%B9%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%84-%D8%AE%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%84-2013#.UwMgu_mSzwm|work=Amwal Magazine|accessdate=18 February 2014|language=Arabic|date=December 29, 2013}} and has been named a Young Global Leader by the [[World Economic Forum]].{{Cite web|url=http://widgets.weforum.org/ygl-2016/|title=Young Global Leaders class of 2016|website=widgets.weforum.org|access-date=2016-09-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thegulfonline.com/Articles.aspx?ArtID=5376|title=Stepping on the gas}} Jafar repeatedly stressed the importance of the [[Private sector development|expansion]] of the [[private sector]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/15/business/energy-environment/cracking-the-energy-puzzles-of-the-21st-century.html?pagewanted=all|title=Cracking the Energy Puzzles of the 21st Century|last=|first=|date=|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-11-17|language=en}} to fully develop the potential of [[Natural resource|natural resources]] in the [[Middle East]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/video/2015/03/12/iraq-oil-needs-regulatory-revamp-ceo.html|title=Iraq oil needs regulatory revamp: CEO|website=CNBC|access-date=2018-11-17}} He argued for an expansion of the private sector and cited the Sharjah region, the UAE base of Crescent's operations, as role model for possible developments.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/business/energy/new-investment-models-needed-to-boost-mena-oil-and-gas-competitiveness-1.742335|title=New investment models needed to boost Mena oil and gas competitiveness|work=The National|access-date=2018-11-17|language=en}} Jafar is an advocate of balanced and [[sustainable energy]] development. He stated that the Arab world should keep the focus on their core strengths oil and gas whilst working on diversification and development of sustainable energy supply sources.{{Cite news|url=https://www.globalbankingandfinance.com/majid-jafar-outlines-vision-for-sustainable-energy-future-in-the-middle-east/|title=MAJID JAFAR OUTLINES VISION FOR SUSTAINABLE ENERGY FUTURE IN THE MIDDLE EAST|date=2013-10-30|work=Global News, Analysis, Awards for Banking, Finance, Technology sector|access-date=2018-11-17|language=en-GB}} He is a trustee of the [[Arab Forum for Environment and Development]] (AFED){{Cite web|url=http://www.afedonline.org/en/trustees.aspx|title=Afed Trustees|website=www.afedonline.org|access-date=2016-09-30}} and a board member at the Iraqi Energy Institute, a member of the Young Presidents Organisation{{Cite web|url=http://www.ypo.org/2016/06/what-does-it-mean-to-be-a-young-global-leader/|title=YPO {{!}} What Does It Mean to Be a Young Global Leader?|website=www.ypo.org|access-date=2016-09-30}} and of the panel of senior advisors of the Royal Institute of International Affairs ([[Chatham House]]) in London chaired by former UK Prime Minister [[John Major]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.chathamhouse.org/about/governance/panel-senior-advisers|title=Panel of Senior Advisers|access-date=2016-09-30}} He is also a member of the board at the [[Higher Colleges of Technology]] (HCT) industry advisory council{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=9E1zCgAAQBAJ&pg=PR19&lpg=PR19&ots=tzhE5YEIoj&focus=viewport&dq=%22Majid+Jafar%22+HCT&hl=en|title=Performance and Progress: Essays on Capitalism, Business, and Society|last=Rangan|first=Subramanian|date=2015-08-21|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=9780191061769|language=en}} and of the International Advisory Council of the [[Atlantic Council]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.atlanticcouncil.org/about/international-advisory-board|title=International Advisory Board|last=Council|first=Atlantic|work=Atlantic Council|access-date=2018-11-17|language=en-gb}} and serves as accredited director of the [[Institute of Directors]]. Jafar is a member of the board of the Sharjah Chamber of Commerce (UAE), the Sharjah Expo, and the Iraqi-British Friendship Society.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/people/16669954-majid-hamid-jafar|title=Majid Jafar, Chief Executive Officer, Crescent Petroleum Co International UK Ltd|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bloomberg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-17}} == Economic development == Jafar has served as the vice-chairman of the World Economic Forum's Global Agenda Council on Youth Unemployment{{cite web|title=Global Agenda Council on Youth Unemployment 2012–2013|url=http://www.weforum.org/content/global-agenda-council-youth-unemployment-2012-2013}} and the founder of the “Arab Stabilization Plan”, which focuses on job creation through critical infrastructure investments to achieve economic stability and prevent instability.{{cite web|title=‘Arab Stabilization Plan’ With Mr. Majid H. Jafar|url=http://www.stimson.org/events/arab-stabilization-plan-with-mr-majid-h-jafar/}} He has written a number of articles on social and economic issues affecting the Arab world, including in the [[Financial Times]]{{cite web|title=Why Oil is Indispensable to a Healthy Global Economy|url=http://www.creekminerals.com/2012/10/22/majid-jafar-ceo-of-crescent-petroleum-explains-why-oil-is-indispensable-to-a-healthy-global-economy/}} and the [[The Daily Telegraph|Daily Telegraph]].{{cite web|last1=Jafar|first1=Majid|last2=Berglof|first2=Erik|title=Iraq violence demonstrates urgency for a Middle East 'Marshall Plan’|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/comment/10901740/Iraq-violence-demonstrates-urgency-for-a-Middle-East-Marshall-Plan.html|publisher=Telegraph|accessdate=24 June 2014}} In 2014, he was listed among the world's 100 most powerful Arabs and amongst the leading "Thinkers" by Arabian Business.{{cite web|title=World's 100 Most Powerful Arabs|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/world-s-100-most-powerful-arabs-2014-543949.html?view=profile&itemid=544020#.U5grsigVeYF|website=Arabian Business.com|publisher=Arabian Business.com|accessdate=11 June 2014|date=31 March 2014}} In March 2014 Jafar co-launched the Centre for Economic Growth (CEG) in Abu Dhabi in partnership with the [[INSEAD]] business school. He serves as the founding chair of the CEG Business Council.{{cite web|title=Centre for Economic Growth launched in Abu Dhabi|url=http://www.emirates247.com/business/economy-finance/centre-for-economic-growth-launched-in-abu-dhabi-2014-03-24-1.542853|website=Emirates 24/7|publisher=Emirates 24/7|accessdate=11 June 2014|date=March 24, 2014}} He sits on the Middle East Advisory board of [[Carnegie Endowment for International Peace|Carnegie Endowment]]{{Cite web|url=http://carnegie-mec.org/about/?lang=en|title=About|access-date=2016-09-30}} and Harvard Business School, and the board of the [[Queen Rania of Jordan|Queen Rania]] Foundation {{Cite web|url=http://www.qrf.org/page/board_of_directors|title=Our Board of Directors {{!}} QRF|website=www.qrf.org|access-date=2016-09-30}} and is a founding patron of the Prince's Trust International in the [[United Kingdom|UK]].{{Cite web|url=http://princestrustinternational.org/who-we-are/|title=Who we are {{!}} Princes Trust International|website=princestrustinternational.org|access-date=2016-09-30}} He is co-chair of the Business Backs Education campaign.{{cite web|last1=Gurney-Read|first1=Josie|title=Boris Johnson: businesses need to 'step up' to support education|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/educationnews/11159333/Boris-Johnson-businesses-need-to-step-up-to-support-education.html|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=18 December 2014|date=13 October 2014}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/education/BBE-EPG-Report2015.pdf|title=Business Backs Education|last=|first=|date=|website=UNESCO|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} In September 2014, he was co-chair of the World Economic Forum Special Meeting in [[Istanbul]] on 'Unlocking Resources for Regional Development'. He was also chairman of the March 2016 'Change in the Middle East: new lines in the sand?' conference held by the [[Ditchley Foundation]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.ditchley.co.uk/conferences/past-programme/2010-2019/2016/middle-east|title=Change in the Middle East: new lines in the sand? - The Ditchley Foundation|website=www.ditchley.co.uk|access-date=2016-09-30}} Jafar authored the opening chapter of '''Performance and Progress: Essays on Capitalism, Business and Society''' published in 2015 by [[Oxford University Press]].{{Cite journal|title=Performance and Progress: Essays on Capitalism, Business, and Society - Oxford Scholarship|url=http://www.oxfordscholarship.com/view/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780198744283.001.0001/acprof-9780198744283|language=en|doi=10.1093/acprof:oso/9780198744283.001.0001/acprof-9780198744283}} == Education philanthropy == The Jafar family has supported the Jafar Research Professorship of Petroleum Engineering at Cambridge University{{Cite web|url=http://www-g.eng.cam.ac.uk/125/1975-2000/enginuity/issue5/index.html|title=Enginuity|website=www-g.eng.cam.ac.uk|access-date=2016-09-30}} and the Jafar Centre for Executive Education at the American University of Sharjah. In 2015, the Jafar Hall and the Jafar Gallery were opened by the [[Prince of Wales]] at [[Eton College]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/education/article4464416.ece|title=Eton’s £18m hall is open to debate {{!}} The Times|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-09-30}} ==Personal life== He is married to Lynn Barghout Jafar, and they have two children.{{cite web|url=http://www.louloufoundation.org/lynn-jafar.html|title=Team - Lynn Barghout Jafar|website=www.louloufoundation.org|accessdate=31 May 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://gulfnews.com/news/uae/society/new-centre-for-people-of-determination-opens-in-dubai-1.2123426|title=New centre for people of determination opens in Dubai|first=Staff|last=Report|date=12 November 2017|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jafar, Majid}} [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:Emirati businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of SOAS, University of London]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Emirati engineers]] [[Category:Emirati people of Iraqi descent]] [[Category:Alumni of Churchill College, Cambridge]] [[Category:People educated at Eton College]]

'''Oldřich Klimecký''' (* 16 February 1940) [[Entrepreneurship|Czech entrepreneur]], [[researcher]], [[Management|manager]], and former director of Mostecká uhelná společnost.
== Career == After graduating from [[Technical University of Ostrava|VSB-Technical University of Ostrava]] (VSB-TUO), he spent most of his life devoted to [[Brown coal|brown-coal mining]] research in then [[Czechoslovakia]]. At VSB-TUO he also earned the academic title of CSc (a Doctoral-equivalent degree). After the [[Velvet Revolution]] in November 1989, he became the director of the Brown Coal Research Institute (Výzkumný ústav pro hnědé uhlí) in Most.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zpravy.ihned.cz/c1-60034470-mostecka-uhelna-svycarsko-soud|title=Kauza Mostecká uhelná, dějství druhé: Soud si předvolal absentéry Koláčka a Klimeckého|first=|last=ČTK|date=9 June 2013|publisher=}}</ref>
When the Czech Ministry of Industry and Trade began to address the very poor situation at Mostecká uhelná společnost (MUS) in 1995, it started looking for a new CEO for the mining company. The winner of the selection procedure was Oldřich Klimecký, who was tasked with restructuring MUS as quickly as possible, so that for the future Czech power supply, mining would continue on prospective sites only and end everywhere else.
Upon agreement with the representatives of the Ministry of Industry and Trade, the National Property Fund, the regions and major shareholders, all of whom were members of the Board of Directors of MUS, Oldřich Klimecký initiated fundamental changes in the management of the entire company and the company’s transition to a [[market economy]]. In cooperation with the new management of MUS, he created new economic and business rules for MUS and succeeded in stabilising MUS within a few short years and securing its future.
Oldřich Klimecký has long been interest in the development of the entire Most region and has supported the development of the municipalities located there. Under his direction, MUS provided financial support in the tens of millions of crowns. He was also greatly involved in the construction of the Hippodrome, which was built on former mining dumps. The [[Hippodrome]] project in Most, which is part of the Velebudice land rehabilitation park, is one of the most important projects of the Czech land rehabilitation school.<ref name="penize.cz">{{cite web|url=http://rejstrik.penize.cz/oldrich-klimecky|title=Oldřich Klimecký, 7. 2. 2017 - Obchodní rejstřík - Peníze.cz|publisher=}}</ref>
Oldřich Klimecký has also long been engaged in politics in the Most region. He became a member of the Most municipal council in 1994, representing ODS. Oldřich Klimecký still lives in Most, now as a retiree and is no longer involved in either business or politics.<ref name="penize.cz"/>
== MUS case == In October 2013, he was sentenced to 37 months in prison by the [[Swiss]] court of first instance in [[Bellinzona]] for fraud and money laundering in connection with Appian’s purchase of a minority package of MUS shares from the Czech government in 1999.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/domaci/246882-kraus-mus-jsme-nevytunelovali-ale-zachranili/?mobileRedirect=off|title=Kraus: MUS jsme nevytunelovali, ale zachránili|first=Česká|last=televize|publisher=}}</ref> Due to his advanced age and poor health, he has not attended any of the court hearings, always using the possibility to be represented by an [[Attorney at law|attorney]]. As all of his assets and even part of his old-age pension have been seized in the Czech Republic due to the criminal proceedings, he has to be represented by an attorney appointed to him ex officio. After 15 years of continuous investigation, Oldřich Klimecký has given up on justice, lives a secluded life, does not comment on the case and does not communicate with the media.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rozhlas.cz/zpravy/politika/_zprava/oldrich-klimecky-se-nedostavil-ke-svycarskemu-soudu-v-kauze-mus-je-doma-v-moste--1211768|title=Oldřich Klimecký se nedostavil ke švýcarskému soudu v kauze MUS. Je doma v Mostě|publisher=}}</ref>
== References == <references />

revision.text:
In [[business]] or [[commerce]], an '''order''' is a stated intention, either spoken or written, to engage in a commercial transaction for specific products or services. From a buyer's point of view it expresses the intention to buy and is called a [[purchase order]]. From a seller's point of view it expresses the intention to sell and is referred to as a [[Sales Order|sales order]]. When the purchase order of the buyer and the sales order of the seller agree, the orders become a [[contract]] between the buyer and seller. Within an organization, the term order may be used to refer to a [[work order]] for manufacturing, a [[preventive maintenance]] order, or an order to make repairs to a facility. In many businesses, orders are used to collect and report [[cost]]s and [[revenue]]s according to well-defined purposes. Then it is possible to show for what purposes costs have been incurred. ==Spoken orders== Businesses such as [[retail store]]s, [[restaurant]]s and [[filling station]]s conduct business with their customers by accepting orders that are spoken or implied by the buyer's actions. Taking a shopping cart of merchandise to a check-out counter is an implied intent to buy the merchandise. Placing a [[take-out]] or eat-in order at a restaurant is a spoken purchase order. Putting gasoline in one's tank at a filling station is an implied order. The seller usually expects immediate payment by cash, check or credit card for these purchases, and the seller provides the buyer with a receipt for the payment. In legal terms, this form of business order is an "[[implied in fact contract]]". ==Steps in commercial orders== In commerce, various business documents are used to record the negotiation of an agreement to buy and sell, record the agreement itself, and record compliance with the agreement and closure of the contract. An agreement to buy and sell is a form of contract. There are five basic requirements for a contract to exist between two parties: agreement, voluntary, consideration, capacity, and legality. A sixth requirement of "in writing" sometimes applies.{{cite book |last=Mallor |first=Jane P. |author2=A. James Barnes |author3=Thomas Bowers |author4=Michael J. Phillips |author5=Arlen W. Langvardt |title=Business Law and the Regulatory Environment: Concepts and Cases |publisher=Irwin/McGraw-Hill |year=1998 |pages=175 |isbn=0-256-19716-4}} The main concern for commercial orders is that there must be '''agreement''' (offer and acceptance) for the order to be a contract. Prior to this, businesses often record the details of negotiations by using a [[request for quotation]], request for bid, sales quotation, or sales bid. Quotations are non-binding and part of the negotiation process. A request for bid can be binding or non-binding, depending on the terms of the bid.{{citation needed|date=July 2007}} Once an agreement or contract is in place, businesses record these as confirmed purchase orders and confirmed sales orders.{{citation needed|date=July 2007}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Commerce ! Buyer's ActionFogarty, Blackstone, Hoffmann. ''Production & Inventory Management'', 2nd Ed. South-Western Publishing Co., 1991. p.510 {{ISBN|0-538-07461-2}} ! Seller's Action |- | Buyer wanting the product and seller selling the product | Search for vendors (sellers) of the product | Marketing and advertising |- | Check product pricing, availability, specifications, delivery costs | Request for Quotation or Request for Bid | [[Sales quote]] or bid created |- | Buyer and seller agree to transaction | [[Purchase order]] recorded | [[Sales order]] recorded |- | Product is shipped from seller to buyer | | [[Packing slip]], ''pro forma'' invoice for certain international shipments |- | Buyer receives product from seller | Packing slip and product is checked with purchase order; product is checked for good condition | |- | Seller sends [[invoice]] to buyer | Match packing slip with purchase order and invoice; record purchase in financial accounts under [[accounts payable]] | Record sales order in financial accounts under [[accounts receivable]] |- | Buyer pays seller | Pay by cash, check or electronic payment; record payment on purchase order | Receive cash, check or electronic payment; record payment on sales order |} ==Uniform Commercial Code== In the US, Article 2 of the [[Uniform Commercial Code]] covers commercial contracts, and section 2-103 gives definitions of terms under this code.[https://www.law.cornell.edu/ucc/2/ Uniform Commercial Code, Article 2] Section 2-106 describes the difference between a '''present sale''' (recorded as a sales order) and a '''sale''' (recorded as a transfer of title to the buyer).
(1) In this Article unless the context otherwise requires "[[contract]]" and "agreement" are limited to those relating to the present or future sale of goods. "Contract for sale" includes both a present sale of goods and a contract to sell goods at a future time. A "sale" consists in the passing of title from the seller to the buyer for a price (Section 2-401). A "present sale" means a sale which is accomplished by the making of the contract.
==Aggregate level of orders== In their "Advance Monthly Sales for Retail Trade and Food Services", the US Census Bureau publishes estimates of US retail and food services sales.[https://www.census.gov/svsd/www/retail.html Advance Monthly Sales For Retail And Food Services: Latest Release] These "sales" are orders that have been filled; payment has been made or is an account receivable. In their "Preliminary Report on Manufacturers' Shipments, Inventories and Orders", the US Census Bureau publishes statistics for "new orders", shipments, "unfilled orders" and inventories for manufactured durable goods. This gives an indication whether trade is increasing or decreasing for manufactured durable goods in the US.[https://www.census.gov/indicator/www/m3/index.htm Manufacturers' Shipments, Inventories, & Orders (M3)] ==See also== * [[Backlog (disambiguation)]] * [[Bill of sale]] * [[Contract of sale]] * [[Delivery order]] * [[Distribution (business)]] * [[Marketing]] * [[Order (exchange)]] (stock market) * [[Replenishment (disambiguation)]] * [[Supply chain]] ==References== {{Refimprove|date=July 2007}} {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Order (Business)}} [[Category:Business terms]] [[Category:Business law]] [[ru:Подряд (договор)]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | | name = PDL BioPharma | logo = | type = Public | traded_as = {{NASDAQ|PDLI}}
[[Russell 2000 Index|Russell 2000 Component]] | foundation = | location = | key_people = John McLaughlin ([[CEO]])
[[Peter Garcia]] ([[Chief Financial Officer|CFO]])
Cary Queen (Founder, former vice-president in charge of research)
Lawrence J. Korn (Founder, former president) | industry = [[Biotechnology]] | products = | revenue = $590.4 million (2015){{cite web|url=http://investor.pdl.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=956199|title=PDL BioPharma Announces Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Financial Results (NASDAQ:PDLI)|publisher=}} | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | num_employees = | homepage = {{URL|http://pdl.com/}} }} '''PDL BioPharma''' (known as '''Protein Design Labs''' prior to 2006) is a publicly traded American [[holding company]] that since 2008 manages patents and other intellectual property that had been generated by the company.[http://investing.businessweek.com/Research/stocks/snapshot/snapshot_article.asp?ticker=PDLI Bloomberg company profile] Page accessed May 31, 2016Peter Kolchinsky for In Vivo. July/August 2011 [http://www.racap.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/LastingPeace_IV1107_web-2.pdf How To Create A Lasting Peace Between Biotech Management, Shareholders And Employees] In 2008 in response to shareholder pressure, PDL spun out its active development programs to a company called '''Facet Biotech''' that it capitalized with $400 million.John Carroll for FierceBiotech. 2009 [http://www.fiercebiotech.com/special-report/emerging-drug-developer-facet-biotech Emerging Drug Developer: Facet Biotech][https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/882104/000110465908078237/a08-30875_18k.htm PDL BioPharma, Inc. Form 8-K] December 17, 2008 Protein Design Labs had been founded in 1986 and was a pioneer in [[humanized monoclonal antibody|humanizing]] [[monoclonal antibodies]]. Its humanization technology was used in several monoclonal antibody drugs under licensing and collaboration agreements; such products included [[rituximab]] (Rituxan), [[bevacizumab]] (Avastin), and [[palivizumab]] (Synagis).Thiel KA. A very firm handshake: biotech's growing negotiating power. Nat Biotechnol. 2005 Oct;23(10):1221-6. {{PMID|16211058}} It held its initial public offering in 1992Staff, New York Times. January 30, 1992 [https://www.nytimes.com/1992/01/30/business/finance-briefs-510792.html Finance Briefs] and by 1994 it had 13 compounds in its pipeline, and had partnered its lead product, the humanized monoclonal antibody [[daclizumab]], with [[Hoffmann-La Roche|Roche]] under a license that called for a 15% royalty.The Pharma Letter. July 25, 1994 [http://www.thepharmaletter.com/article/protein-design-rising-star-in-a-depressed-sector Protein Design: Rising Star In A Depressed sector?] Daclizumab became the first humanized monoclonal antibody approved for human use in 1997.Lawrence M. Fisher for The New York Times. December 12, 1997 [https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/12/us/genetically-engineered-drug-approved-for-kidney-transplants.html Genetically Engineered Drug Approved for Kidney Transplants] PDL made another public offering in 2000, at the peak of the biotech IPO window that ran from 1998 to 2001.Wiechers IR, Perin NC, Cook-Deegan R. The emergence of commercial genomics: analysis of the rise of a biotechnology subsector during the Human Genome Project, 1990 to 2004. Genome Med. 2013 Sep 20;5(9):83. {{PMID|24050173}} [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3971346/pdf/gm487.pdf PMC 3971346] In 2003 it settled litigation with [[Genentech]] over royalty payments owed to PDL under their license agreement; annual royalties were anticipated at that time to be around $90M per year.Times Wire Services in the Los Angeles Times. December 02, 2003 [http://articles.latimes.com/2003/dec/02/business/fi-genentech2 Genentech to Pay Royalties in Patent Dispute] These are the kinds of intellectual property and license agreements that PDL manages on behalf of its shareholders since 2008; in 2007 those royalty payments were around $220 million. One of the development programs that PDL had transferred to Facet was the use of daclizumab in indications it had never licensed to Roche, including [[multiple sclerosis]]. Facet partnered that development program with [[Biogen Idec]] which attempted a hostile buy out of Facet for $350M in 2009;Luke Timmerman for Xconomy. September 4, 2009 [http://www.xconomy.com/boston/2009/09/04/biogen-idec-makes-hostile-350m-takeover-bid-for-facet-biotech/ Biogen Idec Makes Hostile $350M Takeover Bid for Facet Biotech] Facet rejected that offer and was purchased by [[Abbvie]] for $450 million in cash the next year.Staff, New York Times Dealbook. March 9, 2010. [https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2010/03/09/abbott-to-buy-facet-biotech-for-67-premium/ Abbott to Buy Facet Biotech for 67% Premium] The FDA approved daclizumab for multiple sclerosis in 2016 under the trade name Zinbryta.[http://www.fda.gov/NewsEvents/Newsroom/PressAnnouncements/ucm504000.htm FDA News Release: FDA approves Zinbryta to treat multiple sclerosis] May 27, 2016 ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://pdl.com/ Official website] [[Category:Biotechnology companies of the United States]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]]

{{Infobox person |name = Peter Herrndorf, CC OOnt | honorific_suffix = {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|OC OOnt|size=100%}} |image = |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1940|10|27}} |birth_place = [[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]] |death_date = |death_place = |other_names = |known_for = |occupation = Performing arts executive |alma_mater = [[University of Manitoba]]
[[Dalhousie University]]
[[Harvard Business School]] |nationality = |awards = [[Order of Canada]]
[[Order of Ontario]] }} '''Peter A. Herrndorf''', {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|CC|OOnt}} (born October 27, 1940) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] lawyer and media businessman. He is the president and chief executive officer of the [[National Arts Centre]]. Born in [[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]], he graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in [[political science]] and English from the [[University of Manitoba]] in 1962 and a law degree from [[Dalhousie University]] in 1965.{{cite news |first= Judy |last= Steed |title= The big shakers at the corp|publisher= Globe and Mail |page= P10|date= May 22, 1982 }} In 1970, he received an [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] from the [[Harvard Business School]]. Herrndorf joined the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] (CBC) as a TV reporter/editor in Winnipeg beginning in 1965 a day after graduating from Dalhousie. Later that year, he moved to CBC Edmonton as a current affairs producer. In 1967, he transferred to Toronto as a producer of the network current affairs series ''The Way It Is''. In 1979, he became Special Assistant to the Vice President and General Manager of the CBC English Network. Herrndorf was appointed head of TV current affairs in 1979, and later network vice-president. Herrndorf is credited with moving CBC Television's nightly network newscast, ''The National'' from 11 p.m. to 10 p.m. and for helping to create the nightly, network public affairs program, ''The Journal''.{{cite web | url = https://nac-cna.ca/en/bio/peter-herrndorf | title = Biographies: Peter Herrndorf | publisher = National Arts Centre | accessdate = September 25, 2017}} He was publisher of ''[[Toronto Life]]'' from 1983 to 1992, and was chairman and CEO of [[TVOntario]] from 1992 to 1999. In 1993, he was made an Officer of the [[Order of Canada]]. He also received honorary [[Doctor of Laws]] degrees from [[York University]] in 1989, from the [[University of Winnipeg]] in 1993, and from Dalhousie University in 2000. In 1998, he was awarded the [[John Drainie Award]]. In 2007, he was awarded the Order of Ontario for having "revolutionized Canadian broadcasting, publishing and the performing arts at organizations such as the CBC, Toronto Life Magazine, TV Ontario and the National Arts Centre".{{cite web|title=Order of Ontario Recipients Announced|url=http://www.citizenship.gov.on.ca/english/news/2007/n20071219.shtml|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513214020/http://www.citizenship.gov.on.ca/english/news/2007/n20071219.shtml|archivedate=2008-05-13|df=}} He was appointed to the board of directors of the CBC in February, 2005 for a five-year term. He is also on the board of governors of the [[University of Ottawa]]. On June 30, 2017, it was announced that he was named a [[Order of Canada|Companion of the Order of Canada]] by [[Governor General of Canada|Governor General]] [[David Johnston]] for "his transformative leadership in Canada's artistic community and for his enduring commitment to building a thriving national arts scene."{{cite news|url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/local-news/nine-ottawans-appointed-to-the-order-of-canada| title=Nine Ottawans appointed to the Order of Canada| first=Lauren| last=Malyk| date=June 30, 2017| publisher=[[Ottawa Citizen]]}} He is married to Eva Czigler and has two children: Katherine and Matthew Herrndorf. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=Chairman and CEO of [[TVOntario]] | years=1992-1999 | before=[[Bernard Ostry]] | after=[[Isabel Bassett]] }} {{s-end}} ==External links== *[https://archive.is/20070311112217/http://www.gg.ca/honours/search-recherche/honours-desc.asp?lang=e&TypeID=orc&id=3151 Order of Canada Citation] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070208191003/http://www.cbc.radio-canada.ca/about/directors/herrndorf.shtml cbc.ca - Peter Herrndorf bio] {{DEFAULTSORT:Herrndorf, Peter}} [[Category:1940 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Schulich School of Law alumni]] [[Category:Dutch emigrants to Canada]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Members of the Order of Ontario]] [[Category:Companions of the Order of Canada]] [[Category:Lawyers in Ontario]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Winnipeg]] [[Category:University of Manitoba alumni]] [[Category:TVOntario executives]] [[Category:People from Amsterdam]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox F1 driver| name = Peter Monteverdi | nationality = {{flagicon|CHE}} Swiss | image= Peter Monteverdi-1.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date|1934|6|7|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Binningen, Switzerland]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1998|7|4|1934|6|7|df=y}} | death_place = [[Binningen, Switzerland]] | Years = {{F1|1961}} | Team(s) = [[MBM (automobile)|MBM]] | Races = 1 (0 starts) | Championships = 0 | Wins = 0 | Podiums = 0 | Points = 0 | Poles = 0 | Fastest laps = 0 | First race = [[1961 German Grand Prix]] | First win = | Last win = | Last race = [[1961 German Grand Prix]] | }} '''Peter Monteverdi''' (7 June 1934 – 4 July 1998) was a Swiss carmaker and creator of the car brand ''[[Monteverdi (car)|Monteverdi]]''. At the beginning of his career, Monteverdi was a [[automobile salesperson|car salesman]]. His father ran a garage and truck business, which Peter used as his initial inspiration. {{cite web|url=http://www.oldracingcars.com/driver/Peter_Monteverdi|title=Peter Monteverdi|first=Allen|last=Brown|website=oldracingcars.com|accessdate=15 August 2018}}In 1957 he acquired the Swiss franchise for [[Ferrari]], subsequently becoming Swiss importer for other international prestige brands including [[List of Rolls-Royce motor cars|Rolls-Royce]] and [[Bentley]].{{cite journal| title = Nachtschicht im Schloss: A report on a concours d'elegance at Schloss Bensberg | authorlink = Bernd Ostmann|journal = [[Auto, Motor und Sport|Auto Motor u. Sport]]| volume = Heft 25 2010| pages = Seite 46 |date = 18 November 2010}} In 1952, he started producing cars under his own name. ==Formula One involvement == Peter Monteverdi was born in [[Binningen, Switzerland|Binningen]], in the northern Swiss canton of [[Basel-Landschaft]]. He engaged in the construction of [[Formula One]] cars from the late 1950s to the early 1960s. In 1961, he built the first Swiss Formula One car, which bore the name [[MBM (automobile)|MBM]] (''Monteverdi Basel Motoren''). He made a single Formula One appearance at the [[1961 Solitude Grand Prix]], where he retired after two laps, and subsequently withdrew his entry for the [[1961 German Grand Prix|German Grand Prix]]John Thompson, "The Formula One Record Book", Leslie Frewin Publishing, 1974. pp. 40-41 having been injured in a prior race. He subsequently retired from race driving. In 1989 Monteverdi bought the [[Onyx (racing team)|Onyx]] Formula One team after its original backer ran into financial difficulties. The team's best result was when [[Stefan Johansson]] finished in third place at the [[1989 Portuguese Grand Prix]]. However, the involvement proved unsustainable and was terminated during the following season. A legacy was the [[Monteverdi Hai 650 F1]] sportscar, of which supposedly six copies were sold until 1994.{{citation needed|date=October 2012}} ==Death== Monteverdi died from cancer on 4 July 1998 in Binningen, in his apartment directly above his own car-assembly workshop.{{cite journal| authorlink = Bernd Ostmann (Ed)| title =Traumautos aus der Schweiz: Monteverdi gestorben| journal = [[Auto, Motor und Sport]]| volume = 1998 Heft 15| pages = Seite 11|date = 15 July 1998}} He was 64. ==Complete Formula One World Championship results== ([[:Template:F1 driver results legend 2|key]]) {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:90%" ! Year ! Entrant ! Chassis ! Engine ! 1 ! 2 ! 3 ! 4 ! 5 ! 6 ! 7 ! 8 ! WDC ! Points |- | [[1961 Formula One season|1961]] ! Piero Monteverdi ! [[MBM (automobile)|MBM]] ! {{about|the general discipline dealing with the development of products|specifics about managing products in the digital space|Software product management}}
{{Multiple issues| {{Update|date=September 2018}} {{Tone|date=September 2018}} {{Cleanup rewrite|date=September 2018|reason=quality standards}} {{Cleanup reorganize|date=September 2018}} }}
{{marketing}} {{Business administration}}
'''Product management''' is an organisational lifecycle function within a company dealing with the planning, forecasting, and production, or marketing of a product or products at all stages of the [[Product lifecycle (marketing)|product lifecycle]]. Similarly, product lifecycle management (PLM)<ref> {{cite book|title=Product Life Cycle in Digital factory|last1=Kurkin|first1=O.|last2=Januška|first2=M.|publisher=International Business Information Management Association (IBIMA)|year=2010|isbn=9780982148945|location=Cairo|pages=1881-1886|script-title=|trans-title=In Knowledge management and innovation: A business competitive edge perspective}}</ref> integrates people, data, processes and business systems. It provides product information for companies and their extended supply chain enterprise.
The role may consist of [[New product development|product development]] and [[product marketing]], which are different (yet complementary) efforts, with the objective of maximizing sales revenues, market share, and profit margins. Product management also involves elimination decisions. Product elimination begins with the identification of elimination candidates, proceeds with the consideration of remedial actions, continues with a projection of the impact on the business as a whole if a candidate product is eventually eliminated, and concludes with the implementation stage, where management determines the elimination strategy for an item.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Argouslidis|first1=P.|last2=Baltas|first2=G.|title=Structure in product line management: The role of formalization in service elimination decisions|journal=Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science|date=2007|volume=35|pages=475–491|doi=10.1007/s11747-006-0004-2}}</ref> The [[product manager]] is often responsible for analyzing market conditions and defining features or functions of a product and for overseeing the production of the product. The role of product management spans many activities from strategic to tactical and varies based on the organizational structure of the company. To maximize the impact and benefits to an organization, Product management must be an independent function separate on its own.
While involved with the entire [[Product lifecycle (marketing)|product lifecycle]], the product management's main focus is on driving [[new product development]]. According to the [[Product Development and Management Association|Product Development and Management Association (PDMA)]], superior and differentiated new products—ones that deliver unique benefits and superior value to the customer—are the number one driver of success and product profitability.<ref>Kahn, Kenneth B. (Editor). The PDMA Handbook of New Product Development. Second Edition. Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley & Sons, 2005. {{ISBN|0-471-48524-1}}</ref>
Depending on the company size and history, product management has a variety of functions and roles. Sometimes there is a product manager, and sometimes the role of product manager is shared by other roles. Frequently there is Profit and Loss (P&L) responsibility as a key metric for evaluating product manager performance. In some companies, the product management function is the hub of many other activities around the product. In others, it is one of many things that need to happen to bring a product to market and actively monitor and manage it in-market. In very large companies, the product manager may have effective control over shipment decisions to customers, when system specifications are not being met.
Product management often serves an inter-disciplinary role, bridging gaps within the company between teams of different expertise, most notably between engineering-oriented teams and commercially oriented teams. For example, product managers often translate business objectives set for a product by Marketing or Sales into engineering requirements (sometimes called a Technical Specification). Conversely, they may work to explain the capabilities and limitations of the finished product back to Marketing and Sales (sometimes called a Commercial Specification). Product managers may also have one or more direct reports who manage operational tasks and/or a [[Change management|change manager]] who can oversee new initiatives. Manufacturing is separate from the research function, the product manager has the responsibility to bridge the gaps if any exist.
In most technology companies, most product managers possess knowledge in the following areas: [[computer science]], business, and [[user experience]].
==Product marketing== {{Cleanup list|section|date=September 2018}} * [[Product Life Cycle Management|Product Life Cycle]] considerations * [[Product differentiation]] * Product naming and branding * Product positioning and outbound messaging * Promoting the product externally with press, customers, and partners * Conducting customer feedback and enabling (pre-production, beta software) * Launching new products to market * Monitoring the competition
==Product development== {{Cleanup list|section|date=September 2018}} * Testing * Identifying new product candidates * Considering new candidates * Gathering the [[voice of customer]]s * Defining [[product requirements document|product requirements]] * Determining business-case and feasibility * Scoping and defining new products at high level * Evangelizing new products within the company * Building product roadmaps, particularly [[technology roadmap]]s * Developing all products on schedule, working to a critical path * Ensuring products are within optimal price margins and up to specifications * Ensuring products are manufacturable and optimizing cost of components and procedures.
==Inbound and outbound==
Many{{what|date=September 2018}} refer to inbound (product development) and outbound (product marketing) functions.<ref>By Robert, Michael on Product Management and Marketing. [http://michael.hightechproductmanagement.com/2006/04/product_management_product_marketing.html Product Management & Product Marketing - A Definition] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210150430/http://michael.hightechproductmanagement.com/2006/04/product_management_product_marketing.html |date=2012-02-10 }}." April 7, 2006. Retrieved March 1, 2012</ref>
Inbound product management (aka inbound marketing) is the "radar" of the organization and involves absorbing information like customer research, competitive intelligence, industry analysis, trends, economic signals and competitive activity<ref name="name">By Steven Haines. "[https://books.google.com/books?id=xTMWzXuPqgwC&pg=PA389&lpg=PA389&dq=inbound+marketing+product+management+requirements&source=bl&ots=GpxjBIyLsV&sig=NgO7hkl0lnRZ092marDRr8H8m68&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wPtPT_nyG8iK0QG-o8HsDQ&ved=0CHwQ6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=inbound&f=false The Product Manager's Desk Reference]." Published by McGraw Hill. Page 390.</ref> as well as documenting requirements and setting [[product strategy]].<ref name="two">By Scott Sehlhorst, Tyner Blain. "[http://tynerblain.com/blog/2007/01/18/foundation-series-inbound-pm-and-outbound-pm/ Foundation Series: Inbound and Outbound Product Management]." January 18, 2007. Retrieved March 1, 2012.</ref>
In comparison, outbound activities are focused on distributing or pushing messages, training sales people, go to market strategies and communicating messages through channels like advertising, PR and events.<ref name="name"/><ref name="two"/>
In many organizations the inbound and outbound functions are performed by the same person.<ref>By Tarquin Clark, Toolbox. "[http://it.toolbox.com/blogs/tarquin/which-is-more-important-inbound-or-outbound-product-management-48362 Which is more important, inbound or outbound product management?]" September 12, 2011. Retrieved March 1, 2012.</ref>
As these terms are under discussion, another way of looking at these activities is upstream and downstream product management, where 'upstream' is referring to any activity that helps to define, create, or improve the product, while 'downstream' refers to any activity that promotes the product.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Product Manager's Handbook|last=Gorchels|first=Linda|publisher=McGraw-Hill|year=2012|isbn=978-0-07-177298-3|location=United States|pages=8–10}}</ref> This avoids the confusion with the term "inbound marketing" which nowadays clearly refers to a way of doing downstream product management, referring to 'making the product accessible', i.e. it can be found by suspects and prospects (compared to 'outbound marketing', where the product is 'pushed' in front of the suspect or prospect). The confusion stems mainly from the mix up between the term "Marketing" as a discipline, comprising Product Management, MarCom (Marketing Communications), etc. and using the same term 'Marketing' as a synonym for 'Promotion' or 'advertising', i.e. taking a product to the market (i.e. 'downstream').
It comes as a surprise that this confusion and ambiguity is hard to understand- because if you name the main (value creating) departments in today's organizations, you can clearly assign to Sales, R&D, Operations, and Marketing their respective core functions and areas of responsibility. The core function of Marketing, that differentiates it from Sales, Operations, and R&D is the ownership of the [[marketing mix]] (= 4 P: Product, Place, Price, Promotion). Still, many organizations put under 'Marketing' only Market Communications (MarCom), which is just the operational end of marketing and only a subset of what 'Promotion' comprises. From a Product Management perspective, MarCom is a supporting function (like IT, HR, Controlling etc.). In organizations, where the Product Management is weak or not existent, its tasks are taken over by the other departments (i.e. sales defines the distribution ('Place'), operations defines the prices, R&D defines the product, MarCom decides on the promotion.
==See also== * [[Aggregate project plan]] * [[Brand management]] * [[Configurator]] * [[Crossing the Chasm]] * [[Customer experience]] * [[Business|Enterprise]] * [[Marketing management]] * [[Mass customization]] * [[Product (business)]] * [[Product life cycle management]] * [[Product manager]] * [[Product marketing]] * [[Product planning]] * [[Requirements management]] * [[Software product management]] * [[Service product management]] * [[Technology roadmap]] * [[User experience]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Dablink|For the American historian, see [[Edward Rosen]]}} '''Edward (Teddy) Ezra Rosen''' (1898 - 6 March 1966) was the founder of [[Ultra Electronics]], one of the [[United Kingdom]]'s largest electronics manufacturers.
==Career== Born the son of Rachel and Samuel Rosen, immigrants from [[Poland]],<ref name=vintage>[http://www.vintage-technology.info/pages/ultra/ultrahistory.htm Vintage Technology: Ultra Electric]</ref> Teddy was educated at the [[Jews' Free School]] in [[Kenton, London|Kenton]], northwest London.<ref>[http://www.jfsalumni.com/drbernsteinsmemoirs/?disp_feature=PFnh55 JFS Alumni]</ref> He joined [[Marconi Company|Marconi]] in the Post Office Wireless Department in 1911.<ref name=vintage/> During [[World War I]] Teddy joined the [[Royal Flying Corps]] where he serviced radios.<ref name=vintage/> In 1920 he founded [[Ultra Electronics|Ultra Electric]] where he was keen on delivering quality [[Antique radio|radio sets]] at a reasonable price.<ref name=vintage/> He was Chairman of the ''Radio Manufacturers' Association''<ref>[http://www.terramedia.co.uk/reference/documents/opening_of_bbc_television.htm Opening of BBC Television]</ref> and served as Chairman of the [[Television and Radio Industries Club]] in 1953/54.<ref>[http://www.tric.org.uk/main/past_presidents_02.html Television and Radio Industries Club] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100204045402/http://www.tric.org.uk/main/past_presidents_02.html |date=2010-02-04 }}</ref>
He was still [[Chairman]] on Ultra Electric (Holdings) Group in 1961<ref>[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1961/1961%20-%200064.html In brief] Flight Magazine, 13 January 1961</ref> but resigned shortly after the acquisition of the business by [[Thorn Electrical Industries]] in October of that year.<ref>[http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/wiki/Ultra_Electric Graces Guide: Ultra Electric]</ref>
In 1960 he became Chairman of the ''British Technion Society'' which supports the [[Technion – Israel Institute of Technology|Israel Institute of Technology]].<ref>[http://www.britishtechnionsociety.org/ReadContent93.aspx British Technion Society] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090819212221/http://www.britishtechnionsociety.org/ReadContent93.aspx |date=2009-08-19 }}</ref> The Institute awarded him an honorary [[Doctor of Science]] in [[Technology]] in 1966.<ref>[http://pard.technion.ac.il/update/honorlist.html Technion: Honor List]</ref>
In retirement he was still giving talks on his career.<ref>[http://www.frars.org.uk/cgi-bin/render.pl?parameter=&pageid=1323&sessionid=&printer=true Wireless Manufacturing between the Wars] Flight Refuelling Amateur Radio Society, 4 February 2007</ref>
He died on 6 March 1966, in [[Hove]].<ref>National Probate Calendar</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Underlinked|date=November 2015}}
'''Total benefits of ownership (TBO)''' is a calculation that tries to summarise the positive effects of the acquisition of a [[Business plan|plan]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.auditmypc.com/tbo.asp|title = TBO Definitions|date = |accessdate = 2015-11-01|website = |publisher = Audit My PC|last = |first = }}</ref> It is an estimate of all the values that will affect a business. It is a financial estimate intended to help buyers and owners determine the direct and indirect benefits of a product or system.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.asiaonline.net/EN/LanguageStudio/BenefitsROIAndTCO.aspx|title = Understanding Return On Investment (ROI) and Total Cost and Benefit of Ownership (TCBO)|date = |accessdate = 2015-10-28|website = Understanding Return On Investment (ROI) and Total Cost and Benefit of Ownership (TCBO)|publisher = Asia Online|last = |first = }}</ref> It is used to determine potential [[Return On Investment|Return on Investment]] (ROI). The usage of TBO may lead to increase in efficiency and productivity of a business, improvements in decision-making or improvements in the workforce. It helps to identify important areas which a business should be focusing on, as well as uncovering the hidden aspects of the decisions made by the firm.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://searchdatacenter.techtarget.com/definition/total-benefit-of-ownership-TBO|title = total benefit of ownership (TBO) definition|date = |accessdate = 2015-10-30|website = |publisher = TechTarget|last = |first = }}</ref>
== Use of concept == TBO goes beyond the initial purpose or implementation benefit to consider the full benefit of a decision or an asset over its [[Product lifetime|useful life]]. A TBO analysis often shows there can be a large difference between the short term benefit to the business and its long term benefit. This can include [[Operating cost|operational cost]] savings, productivity improvements, enhancements to a business’s ability to compete, greater [[employee retention]], increased [[brand equity]] and expanding sales reach.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.fuzebox.com/files/pdf/whitepapers/TCO.pdf|title = Analysing Your web conferencing: Total Cost of Ownership|date = |accessdate = 2015-10-30|website = |publisher = fuzebox|last = |first = }}</ref> For example, a small company can now have access to the rest of the world's markets without the costs of travel. The decisions made from TBO analysis help adding monetary profit into the company's account.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b7FRGdB4EVg|title = How to show Total Benefits of Ownership [tm]|date = |accessdate = 2015-11-01|website = |publisher = Senior Advisory Group|last = |first = }}</ref>
== Importance of TBO == While many companies perform [[Total Cost of Ownership]] (TCO) analysis, TBO is considered to be as important as TCO. TCO aims to minimise the total cost of the business, whereas TBO targets the maximum value of the project. Enterprise decision makers often use both methods to estimate the actual value of an investment or strategic venture.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://dash.harvard.edu/bitstream/handle/1/3450060/Hart_CostsBenefits.pdf?sequence=4|title = The Costs and Benefits of Ownership: A Theory of Vertical and Lateral Integration|date = |accessdate = 2015-11-02|website = |publisher = Harvard University|last = |first = }}</ref>
When considering a business proposition, the enterprise decision makers always consider other alternatives while deciding whether the original plan is the best. An advantage of using TBO is that it identifies the value of the short term and the long-term benefits of the propositions. This system helps the company to prioritise the importance of each decision. This analysis not only serves as a tool to reduce cost but also as a way to plan the future of the business, in a more detailed and sophisticated way.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs11740-011-0313-2|title = Linking total costs and benefits of ownership (TCBO) and process chain simulation for integrated assessment of manufacturing technologies and processes|date = |accessdate = 2015-10-28|doi=10.1007/s11740-011-0313-2|volume=5|pages=557–564 | last1 = Denkena | first1 = B. |journal=Production Engineering}}</ref> For example, a company is considering whether to invest in a long-term project, such as [[infrastructure]]. TBO will consider whether the long-term benefit may outweigh the short-term benefits of [[opportunity cost]]; whether the money spent on investment may have a better alternate purpose, e.g. using the budget to improve training schemes for workers.
== Examples of different industries using Total Benefits of Ownership ==
=== Retailing industry with the use of Internet === The TBO concept is widely used within the web industry. For example, TBO identifies the benefits of using the Internet in a business. These include the exclusion of fixed cost (i.e. rent), as well as the decreasing cost of online advertisement.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.wilsonmar.com/1tco.htm|title = Total Cost and Benefit of Ownership (TCBO)|date = |accessdate = 2015-11-04|website = |publisher = WilsonMar|last = |first = }}</ref>
Some of the key elements incorporated in the benefit of ownership within retailing industry. * Cheaper transportation cost * Increase in global demand for products * Decrease in variable cost ( i.e. cheaper wages) * Benefits of outsourcing
=== Computer and software industries etc<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.nashnetworks.ca/total-cost-of-ownership-tco-of-it.htm|title = Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) of IT|date = |accessdate = 2015-11-02|website = Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) of IT|publisher = Nash Networks Inc|last = |first = }}</ref> === * Software becomes more user-friendly * Quicker data analysis * Greater data storage space
== See also == *[[Total cost of ownership]] (TCO) *[[Return on investment|Return on Investment]] *[[Profit (economics)|Profit]] *[[Productivity]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
